[52:33] "Doth our law judge any man before it hear him?"  He showeth that they neither know the Law, nor do the Law; for if that Law commandeth to kill no man without first hearing him, and they before hearing were eager for this deed, they were transgressors of the Law.

[52:34] And because they said, "None of the rulers hath believed on him" ( ver.

[52:35] ), therefore the Evangelist informs us that Nicodemus was "one of them," to show that even rulers believed on Him; for although they showed not yet fitting boldness, still they were becoming attached to Christ.

[52:36] Observe how cautiously he rebukes them; he said not, "Ye desire to kill him, and condemn the man for a deceiver without proof"; but spake in a milder way, hindering their excessive violence, and their inconsiderate and murderous disposition.

[52:37] Wherefore he turns his discourse to the Law, saying, "Except it hear him carefully, and know what he doeth".

[52:38] So that not a bare "hearing," but "careful hearing" is required.

[52:39] For the meaning of, "know what he doeth," is, "what he intendeth," "on what account," "for what purpose," "whether for the subversion of the order of things and as an enemy".

[52:40] Being therefore perplexed, because they had said, "None of the rulers hath believed on him," they addressed him, neither vehemently, nor yet with forbearance.

[52:41] For tell me, after he had said, "The Law judgeth no man," how doth it follow that they should say,  Ver.

[52:42] "Art thou also of Galilee?"   When they ought to have shown that they had not sent to summon Him without judgment, or that it was not fitting to allow Him speech, they take the reply rather in a rough and angry manner.

[52:43] "Search, and look: for out of Galilee hath arisen no prophet".

[52:44] Why, what had the man said? that Christ was a prophet? No; he said, that He ought not to be slain unjudged; but they replied insolently, and as to one who knew nothing of the Scriptures; as though one had said, "Go, learn," for this is the meaning of, "Search, and look".

[52:45] What then did Christ? Since they were continually dwelling upon Galilee and "The Prophet," to free all men from this erroneous suspicion, and to show that He was not one of the prophets, but the Master of the world, He said,  Chap.

[52:46] viii.

[52:47] ver.

[52:48] "I am the light of the world".

[52:49] Not "of Galilee," not of Palestine, nor of Judaea.

[52:50] What then say the Jews?  Ver.

[52:51] "Thou bearest record of thyself, thy record is not true".

[52:52] Alas! for their folly, He continually referred them to the Scriptures, and now they say, "Thou bearest record of thyself".

[52:53] What was the record He bare? "I am the light of the world".

[52:54] A great thing to say, great of a truth, but it did not greatly amaze them, because He did not now make Himself equal to the Father, nor assert that He was His Son, nor that He was God, but for a while calleth Himself "a light".

[52:55] They indeed desired to disprove this also, and yet this was a much greater thing than to say,  "He that followeth Me, shall not walk in darkness".

[52:56] Using the words "light" and "darkness" in a spiritual sense, and meaning thereby "abideth not in error".

[52:57] In this place He draweth on Nicodemus, and bringeth him in as having spoken very boldly, and praiseth the servants who had also done so.

[52:58] For to "cry aloud," is the act of one desirous to cause that they also should hear.

[52:59] At the same time He hinteth at these who were secretly contriving treacheries, being both in darkness and error, but that they should not prevail over the light.

[52:60] And He remindeth Nicodemus of the words which He had uttered before, "Every one that doeth evil hateth the light, neither cometh to the light, lest his deeds should be reproved".

[52:61] ( c.

[52:62] iii.

[52:63] ) For since they had asserted that none of the rulers had believed on Him, therefore He saith, that "he that doeth evil cometh not to the light," to show that their not having come proceedeth not from the weakness of the light, but from their own perverse will.

[52:64] "They answered and said unto Him, Dost thou bear witness to thyself?"  What then saith He?  Ver.

[52:65] "Though I bear record of Myself, My record is true; for I know whence I come, and whither I go; but ye cannot tell whence I come".

[52:66] What He had before said, these men bring forward as if it had been specially asserted.

[52:67] What then doth Christ? To refute this, and to show that He used those expressions as suitable to them and to their suspicions, who supposed Him to be a mere man, He saith, "Though I bear record of Myself, My record is true, for I know whence I come".

[52:68] What is this? "I am of God, am God, the Son of God, and God Himself is a faithful witness unto Himself, but ye know Him not; ye willingly err, knowing ye pretend not to know, but say all that ye say according to mere human imagination, choosing to understand nothing beyond what is seen".

[52:69] Ver.

[52:70] "Ye judge after the flesh".

[52:71] As to live after the flesh is to live badly, so to judge after the flesh is to judge unjustly.

[52:72] "But I judge no man".

[52:73] Ver.

[52:74] "And yet if I judge, My judgment is true".

[52:75] What He saith, is of this kind; "Ye judge unjustly".

[52:76] "And if," saith some one, "we judge unjustly, why dost Thou not rebuke us? why dost Thou not punish us? why dost Thou not condemn us?" "Because," He saith, "I came not for this".

[52:77] This is the meaning of, "I judge no man; yet if I judge, My judgment is true".

[52:78] "For had I been willing to judge, ye would have been among the condemned.

[52:79] And this I say, not judging you.

[52:80] Yet neither do I tell you that I say it, not judging you, as though I were not confident that had I judged you, I should have convicted you; since if I had judged you, I must justly have condemned you.

[52:81] But now the time of judgment is not yet".

[52:82] He alluded also to the judgment to come, saying,  "I am not alone, but I and the Father that sent Me".

[52:83] Here He hinted, that not He alone condemneth them, but the Father also.

[52:84] Then He concealed this, by leading them to His own testimony.

[52:85] Ver.

[52:86] "It is written in your Law, that the testimony of two men is true".

[52:87] What would the heretics say here? (They would say,) "How is he better than man, if we take what he hath said simply? For this rule is laid down in the case of men, because no man by himself is trustworthy.

[52:88] But in the case of God, how can one endure such a mode of speaking? How then is the word 'two' used? Is it because they are two, or because being men they are therefore two? If it is because they are two, why did he not betake himself to John, and say, I bear witness of myself, and John beareth witness of me? Wherefore not to the angels? Wherefore not to the prophets? For he might have found ten thousand other testimonies".

[52:89] But he desireth to show not this only that there are Two, but also that they are of the same Substance.

[52:90] Ver.

[52:91] "Then said they unto Him, Who is thy father? Jesus answered, Ye neither know Me, nor My Father".

[52:92] Because while they knew they spake as though they knew not, and as if trying Him, He doth not even deem them worthy of an answer.

[52:93] Wherefore henceforth He speaketh all more clearly and more boldly; drawing His testimony from signs, and from His teaching of them that followed Him, and by the Cross being near.

[52:94] For, "I know," He saith, "whence I come".

[52:95] This would not greatly affect them, but the adding, "and whither I go," would rather terrify them, since He was not to remain in death.

[52:96] But why said He not, "I know that I am God," instead of, "I know whence I come"? He ever mingleth lowly words with sublime, and even these He veileth.

[52:97] For after saying, "I bear witness of Myself," and proving this, He descendeth to a humbler strain.

[52:98] As though He had said, "I know from whom I am sent, and to whom I depart".

[52:99] For so they could have had nothing to say against it, when they heard that He was sent from Him, and would depart to Him.

[52:100] "I could not have spoken," He saith, "any falsehood, I who am come from thence, and depart thither, to the true God.

[52:101] But ye know not God, and therefore judge according to the flesh.

[52:102] For if having heard so many sure signs and proofs ye still say, 'thy witness is not true,' if ye deem Moses worthy of credit, both as to what he speaketh concerning others and what he speaketh concerning himself, but Christ not so, this is to judge according to the flesh".

[52:103] "But I judge no man".

[52:104] He saith indeed also that "the Father judgeth no man".

[52:105] ( c.

[52:106] v.

[52:107] ) How then doth He here declare, that, "If I judge, My judgment is just, for I am not alone"? He again speaketh in reply to their thoughts.

[52:108] "The judgment which is Mine is the judgment of the Father.

[52:109] The Father, judging, would not judge otherwise than as I do, and I should not judge otherwise than as the Father".

[52:110] Wherefore did He mention the Father? Because they would not have thought that the Son was to be believed unless He received the witness of the Father.

[52:111] Besides, the saying doth not even hold good.

[52:112] For in the case of men when two bear witness in a matter pertaining to another, then their witness is true, (this is for two to witness,) but if one should witness for himself, then they are no longer two.

[52:113] Seest thou that He said this for nothing else but to show that He was of the same Substance, that He needed no other witness, and was in nothing inferior to the Father? Observe at least His independence ;  Ver.

[52:114] "I am One that bear witness of Myself; and the Father that sent Me beareth witness of Me".

[52:115] Had He been of inferior substance, He would not have put this.

[52:116] But now that thou mayest not deem that the Father is included, to make up the number (of two), observe that His power hath nothing different (from the Father's).

[52:117] A man bears witness when he is trustworthy of himself, not when he himself needs testimony, and that too in a matter pertaining to another; but in a matter of his own, where he needs the witness of another, he is not trustworthy.

[52:118] But in this case it is all contrary.

[52:119] For He though bearing witness in a matter of His own, and saying that witness is borne to Him by another, asserteth that He is trustworthy, in every way manifesting His independence.

[52:120] For why, when He had said, "I am not alone, but I and the Father that sent Me," and, "The testimony of two men is true," did He not hold His peace, instead of adding, "I am One that bear witness of Myself"? It was evidently to show His independence.

[52:121] And He placeth Himself first; "I am One that bear witness of Myself".

[52:122] Here He showeth His equality of honor, and that they were profited nothing by saying that they knew God the Father, while they knew not Him.

[52:123] And He saith that the cause of this (ignorance) was that they were not willing to know Him.

[52:124] Therefore He telleth them that it was not possible to know the Father without knowing Him, that even so He might draw them to the knowledge of Him.

[52:125] For since leaving Him they even sought to get the knowledge of the Father, He saith, "Ye cannot know the Father without Me".

[52:126] ( Ver.

[52:127] ) So that they who blaspheme the Son, blaspheme not the Son only, but Him that begat Him also.

[52:128] This let us avoid, and glorify the Son.

[52:129] Had He not been of the same Nature, He would not have spoken thus.

[52:130] For had He merely taught, but been of different Substance, a man might not have known Him, and yet have known the Father; and again, it would not have been that one who knew Him, would have altogether known the Father; for neither doth one who knoweth a man know an Angel.

[52:131] "Yes," replieth some one, "he that knoweth the creation, knoweth God".

[52:132] By no means.

[52:133] Many, or rather I should say, all men know the creation, (for they see it,) but they know not God.

[52:134] Let us then glorify the Son of God, not with this glory (of words) only, but that also which is by works.

[52:135] For the first without the last is nothing.

[52:136] "Behold," saith St.

[52:137] Paul, "thou art called a Jew, and restest in the Law, and makest thy boast of God—thou therefore that teachest another, teachest thou not thyself? Thou that makest thy boast of the Law, through breaking of the Law dishonorest thou God?" ( Rom.

[52:138] ii.

[52:139] , ,.

[52:140] ) Beware lest we also who make boast of the rightness of our faith dishonor God by not manifesting a life agreeable to the faith, causing Him to be blasphemed.

[52:141] For He would have the Christian to be the teacher of the world, its leaven, its salt, its light.

[52:142] And what is that light? It is a life which shineth, and hath in it no dark thing.

[52:143] Light is not useful to itself, nor leaven, nor salt, but showeth its usefulness towards others, and so we are required to do good, not to ourselves only, but to others.

[52:144] For salt, if it salt not, is not salt.

[52:145] Moreover another thing is evident, that if we be righteous, others shall certainly be so also; but as long as we are not righteous, we shall not be able to assist others.

[52:146] Let there be nothing foolish or silly among us; such are worldly matters, such are the cares of this life.

[52:147] Wherefore the virgins were called foolish, because they were busy about foolish, worldly matters, gathering things together here, but laying not up treasure where they ought.

[52:148] Fear there is lest this be our case, fear lest we too depart clothed with filthy garments, to that place where all have them bright and shining.

[52:149] For nothing is more filthy, nothing more impure, than sin.

[52:150] Wherefore the Prophet declaring its nature cried out, "My wounds stink, and are corrupt".

[52:151] ( Ps.

[52:152] xxxviii.

[52:153] ) And if thou wilt fully learn how ill-savored sin is, consider it after it hath been done; when thou art delivered from the desire, when the fire no longer troubleth thee, then shalt thou see what sin is.

[52:154] Consider anger, when thou art calm; consider avarice, when thou dost not feel it.

[52:155] There is nothing more shameful, nothing more accursed, than rapine and avarice.

[52:156] This we continually say, desiring not to vex you, but to gain some great and wonderful advantage.

[52:157] For he who hath not acted rightly after hearing once, may perhaps do so after hearing a second time; and he who hath passed by the second time, may do right after the third.

[52:158] God grant that we, being delivered from all evil things, may have the sweet savor of Christ; for to Him, with the Father and the Holy Ghost is glory, now and ever and world without end, Amen.

[53:1] Homily LIII.

[53:2] John viii.

[53:3] "These words spake Jesus in the treasury, as He taught in the Temple; and no man laid hands on Him, for His hour was not yet come".

[53:4] Oh the folly of the Jews! seeking Him as they did before the Passover, and then having found Him in the midst of them, and having often attempted to take Him by their own or by others' hands without being able; they were not even so awed by His power, but set themselves to their wickedness, and desisted not.

[53:5] For it saith, that they continually made the attempt; "These words spake He in the treasury, teaching in the Temple; and no man laid hands on Him".

[53:6] He spake in the Temple, and in the character of teacher, which was more adapted to rouse them, and He spake those things because of which they were stung, and charged Him with making Himself equal to the Father.

[53:7] For "the witness of two men is true," proveth this.

[53:8] Yet still "He spake these words," It saith, "in the Temple," in the character of teacher, "and no man laid hands on Him, for His hour was not yet come"; that is, it was not yet the fitting time at which He would be crucified.

[53:9] So that even then the deed done was not of their power, but of His dispensation, for they had long desired, but had not been able, nor would they even then have been able, except He had consented.

[53:10] Ver.

[53:11] "Then said Jesus unto them, I go My way, and ye shall seek Me".

[53:12] Why saith He this continually? To shame and terrify their souls; for observe what fear this saying caused in them.

[53:13] Although they desired to kill Him that they might be rid of Him, they yet ask, "whither He goeth," such great things did they imagine from the matter.

[53:14] He desired also to show them another thing, that the deed would not be effected through their force; but He showed it to them in a figure beforehand, and already foretold the Resurrection by these words.

[53:15] Ver.

[53:16] "Then said the Jews, Will he kill himself?"  What then doth Christ? To remove their suspicion, and to show that such an act is sin, He saith,  Ver.

[53:17] "Ye are from beneath".

[53:18] What He saith, is of this kind: "It is no wonder that ye imagine such things, ye who are carnal men, and have no spiritual thoughts, but I shall not do anything of the kind, for,  "I am from above; ye are of the world".

[53:19] Here again He speaketh of their worldly and carnal imaginations, whence it is clear that the, "I am not of this world," doth not mean that He had not taken upon Him flesh, but that He was far removed from their wickedness.

[53:20] For He even saith, that His disciples were "not of the world" ( c.

[53:21] xv.

[53:22] ), yet they had flesh.

[53:23] As then Paul, when he saith, "Ye are not in the flesh" ( Rom.

[53:24] viii.

[53:25] ), doth not mean that they are incorporeal, so Christ when He saith, that His disciples are "not of the world," doth nothing else than testify to their heavenly wisdom.

[53:26] Ver.

[53:27] "I said therefore unto you that…if ye believe not that I am He, ye shall die in your sins".

[53:28] For if He came to take away the sin of the world, and if it is impossible for men to put that off in any other way except by the washing, it needs must be that he that believeth not must depart hence, having the old man; since he that will not by faith slay and bury that old man, shall die in him, and shall go away to that place to suffer the punishment of His former sins.

[53:29] Wherefore He said, "He that believeth not is judged already" ( c.

[53:30] iii.

[53:31] ); not merely through his not believing, but because he de parteth parteth hence having his former sins upon him.

[53:32] Ver.

[53:33] "Then said they unto Him, Who art thou?"  Oh folly! After so long a time, such signs and teaching, they ask, "Who art thou?" What then saith Christ?  "The same that I told you from the beginning".

[53:34] What He saith, is of this kind; "Ye are not worthy to hear My words at all, much less to learn who I am, for ye say all that ye do, tempting Me, and giving heed to none of My sayings.

[53:35] And all this I could now prove against you".

[53:36] For this is the sense of,  Ver.

[53:37] "I have many things to say and to judge of you".

[53:38] "I could not only prove you guilty, but also punish you; but He that sent Me, that is, the Father, willeth not this.

[53:39] For I am come not to judge the world, but to save the world, since God sent not His Son to judge the world, He saith, but to save the world.

[53:40] ( c.

[53:41] iii.

[53:42] ) If now He hath sent Me for this, and He is true, with good cause I judge no one now.

[53:43] But these things I speak that are for your salvation, not what are for your condemnation".

[53:44] He speaketh thus, lest they should deem that it was through weakness that on hearing so much from them He went not to extremities, or that He knew not their secret thoughts and scoffings.

[53:45] Ver.

[53:46] "They understood not that He spake to them of the Father".

[53:47] Oh folly! He ceased not to speak concerning Him, and they knew Him not.

[53:48] Then when after working many signs, and teaching them, He drew them not to Himself, He next speaketh to them of the Cross, saying,  Ver.

[53:49] ,.

[53:50] "When ye have lifted up the Son of Man, then ye shall know that I Am, and that I speak not of Myself, and that He that sent Me is with Me.

[53:51] And the Father hath not left Me alone".

[53:52] He showeth that He rightly said, "the same that I said unto you from the beginning".

[53:53] So little heed they gave to His words.

[53:54] "When ye have lifted up the Son of Man".

[53:55] "Do ye not expect that ye then shall certainly rid yourselves of Me, and slay Me? But I tell you that then ye shall most know that I Am, by reason of the miracles, the resurrection, and the destruction (of Jerusalem)".

[53:56] For all these things were sufficient to manifest His power.

[53:57] He said not, "Then ye shall know who I am"; for, "when ye shall see," He saith, "that I suffer nothing from death, then ye shall know that I Am, that is, the Christ, the Son of God, who govern all things, and am not opposed to Him".

[53:58] For which cause He addeth, "and of Myself I speak nothing".

[53:59] For ye shall know both My power and My unanimity with the Father.

[53:60] Because the, "of Myself I speak nothing," showeth that His Substance differeth not (from that of the Father), and that He uttereth nothing save that which is in the mind of the Father.

[53:61] "For when ye have been driven away from your place of worship, and it is not allowed you even to serve Him as hitherto, then ye shall know that He doth this to avenge Me, and because He is wroth with those who would not hear Me".

[53:62] As though He had said, "Had I been an enemy and a stranger to God, He would not have stirred up such wrath against you".

[53:63] This also Esaias declareth, "He shall give the wicked in return for His burial" ( Isa.

[53:64] liii.

[53:65] , LXX.

[53:66] ); and David, "Then shall He speak unto them in His wrath" ( Ps.

[53:67] ii.

[53:68] ); and Christ Himself, "Behold, your house is left unto you desolate".

[53:69] ( Matt.

[53:70] xxiii.

[53:71] ) And His parables declare the same thing when He saith, "What shall the Lord of that vineyard do to those husbandmen? He shall miserably destroy those wicked men".

[53:72] ( Matt.

[53:73] xxi.

[53:74] ,.

[53:75] ) Seest thou that everywhere He speaketh thus, because He is not yet believed? But if He will destroy them, as He will, (for, "Bring hither," It saith, "those which would not that I should reign over them, and slay them,") wherefore saith He that the deed is not His, but His Father's? He addresseth Himself to their weakness, and at the same time honoreth Him that begat Him.

[53:76] Wherefore He said not, "I leave your house desolate," but, it "is left"; He hath put it impersonally.

[53:77] But by saying, "How often would I have gathered your children together—and ye would not," and then adding, "is left," He showeth that He wrought the desolation.

[53:78] "For since," He telleth them, "when ye were benefited and healed of your infirmities, ye would not know Me, ye shall know by being punished who I am".

[53:79] "And the Father is with Me".

[53:80] That they may not deem the "who sent Me" to be a mark of inferiority, He saith, "is with Me"; the first belongeth to the Dispensation, the second to the Godhead.

[53:81] "And He hath not left Me alone," for I do always those things that please Him.

[53:82] Again He hath brought down His discourse to a humbler strain, continually setting Himself against that which they asserted, that He was not of God, and that He kept not the Sabbath.

[53:83] To this He replieth, "I do always those things that are pleasing unto Him"; showing that it was pleasing unto Him even that the Sabbath should be broken.

[53:84] So, for instance, just before the Crucifixion He said, "Think ye that I cannot call upon My Father?" ( Matt.

[53:85] xxvi.

[53:86] ) And yet by merely saying, "Whom seek ye?" ( c.

[53:87] xviii.

[53:88] ,  ) He cast them down backwards.

[53:89] Why then saith He not, "Think ye that I cannot destroy you," when He had proved this by deed? He condescendeth to their infirmity.

[53:90] For He took great pains to show that He did nothing contrary to the Father.

[53:91] Thus He speaketh rather after the manner of a man; and as "He hath not left Me alone," was spoken, so also was the, "I do always those things that are pleasing unto Him".

[53:92] Ver.

[53:93] "As He spake these words, many believed on Him".

[53:94] When He brought down His speech to a lowly strain, many believed on Him.

[53:95] Dost thou still ask wherefore He speaketh humbly? Yet the Evangelist clearly alluded to this when he said, "As He spake these things, many believed on Him".

[53:96] By this all but proclaiming aloud to us, "Oh hearer, be not confounded if thou hear any lowly expression, for they who after such high teaching were not yet persuaded that He was of the Father, were with good reason made to hear humbler words, that they might believe".

[53:97] And this is an excuse for those things which shall be spoken in a humble way.

[53:98] They believed then, yet not as they ought, but carelessly and as it were by chance, being pleased and refreshed by the humility of the words.

[53:99] For that they had not perfect faith the Evangelist shows by their speeches after this, in which they insult Him again.

[53:100] And that these are the very same persons he has declared by saying,  Ver.

[53:101] "Then said Jesus to those Jews which believed on Him, If ye continue in My word".

[53:102] Showing that they had not yet received His doctrine, but only gave heed unto His words.

[53:103] Wherefore He speaketh more sharply.

[53:104] Before He merely said, "Ye shall seek Me" ( c.

[53:105] vii.

[53:106] ), but now He addeth what is more, "Ye shall die in your sins".

[53:107] ( c.

[53:108] viii.

[53:109] ) And He showeth how; "because ye cannot when ye are come to that place afterwards entreat Me".

[53:110] "These things which I speak unto the world".

[53:111] By these words He showed that He was now going forth to the Gentiles.

[53:112] But because they still knew not that He spake to them of the Father, He again speaketh of Him, and the Evangelist hath put the reason of the humility of the expressions.

[53:113] If now we will thus search the Scriptures, exactly and not carelessly, we shall be able to attain unto our salvation; if we continually dwell upon them, we shall learn right doctrine and a perfect life.

[53:114] For although a man be very hard, and stubborn, and proud, and profit nothing at other times, yet at least he shall gain fruit from this time, and receive benefit, if not so great as to admit of his being sensible of it, still he shall receive it.

[53:115] For if a man who passes by an ointment-maker's shop, or sitteth in one, is impregnated with the perfume even against his will, much more is this the case with one who cometh to church.

[53:116] For as idleness is born of idleness, so too from working is generated a ready mind.

[53:117] Although thou art full of ten thousand sins, although thou art impure, shun not the tarrying here.

[53:118] "Wherefore," it may be said, "when hearing I do not?" It is no small profit to deem one's self wretched; this fear is not useless, this dread is not unseasonable.

[53:119] If only thou groanest that, "hearing I do not," thou wilt certainly come also to the doing at some time or other.

[53:120] For it cannot be that he who speaks with God, and hears God speak, should not profit.

[53:121] We compose ourselves at once and wash our hands when we desire to take the Bible into them.

[53:122] Seest thou even before the reading what reverence is here? And if we go on with exactness, we shall reap great advantage.

[53:123] For we should not, unless it served to place the soul in reverence, have washed our hands; and a woman if she be unveiled straightway puts on her veil, giving proof of internal reverence, and a man if he be covered bares his head.

[53:124] Seest thou how the outward behavior proclaims the inward reverence? Then moreover he that sits to hear groans often, and condemns his present life.

[53:125] Let us then, beloved, give heed to the Scriptures, and if no other part be so, let the Gospels at least be the subjects of our earnest care, let us keep them in our hands.

[53:126] For straightway when thou hast opened the Book thou shalt see the name of Christ there, and shalt hear one say, "The birth of Jesus Christ was on this wise.

[53:127] When His mother Mary was espoused to Joseph, she was found with Child of the Holy Ghost".

[53:128] ( Matt.

[53:129] i.

[53:130] ) He that heareth this will immediately desire virginity, will marvel at the Birth, will be freed from earthly things.

[53:131] It is not a little thing when thou seest the Virgin deemed worthy of the Spirit, and an Angel talking with her.

[53:132] And this upon the very surface; but if thou perseverest to go on unto the end, thou shalt loathe all that pertains to this life, shalt mock at all worldly things.

[53:133] If thou art rich, thou shalt think nothing of wealth, when thou hearest that she who was (the wife) of a carpenter, and of humble family, became the mother of thy Lord.

[53:134] If thou art poor thou shalt not be ashamed of thy poverty, when thou hearest that the Creator of the world was not ashamed of the meanest dwelling.

[53:135] Considering this, thou wilt not rob, thou wilt not covet, thou wilt not take the goods of others, but wilt rather be a lover of poverty, and despise wealth.

[53:136] And if this be the case, thou shalt banish all evil.

[53:137] Again, when thou seest Him lying in a manger, thou wilt not be anxious to put golden garments about thy child, or to cause thy wife's couch to be inlaid with silver.

[53:138] And if thou carest not for these things, thou wilt not do either the deeds of covetousness and rapine, which are caused by them.

[53:139] Many other things you may gain which I cannot separately enumerate, but they will know who have made the trial.

[53:140] Wherefore I exhort you both to obtain Bibles, and to retain together with the Bibles the sentiments they set forth, and to write them in your minds.

[53:141] The Jews because they gave no heed were commanded to suspend their books from their hands; but we place them not even in our hands but in our house, when we ought to stamp them on our heart.

[53:142] Thus cleansing our present life, we shall obtain the good things that are to come to which may we all attain, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom and with whom, to the Father and the Holy Ghost be glory, now and ever, and world without end, Amen.

[54:1] Homily LIV.

[54:2] John viii.

[54:3] ,  "Then said Jesus to those Jews which believed on Him, If ye continue in My word, then are ye My disciples indeed.

[54:4] And ye shall know the truth, and the truth shall make you free".

[54:5] Beloved, our condition needs much endurance; and endurance is produced when doctrines are deeply rooted.

[54:6] For as no wind is able by its assaults to tear up the oak, which sends down its root into the lower recesses of the earth, and is firmly clenched there; so too the soul which is nailed by the fear of God none will be able to overturn.

[54:7] Since to be nailed is more than to be rooted.

[54:8] Thus the Prophet prayeth, saying, "Nail my flesh by Thy fear" ( Ps.

[54:9] cxix.

[54:10] , LXX.

[54:11] ); "do Thou so fix and join me, as by a nail riveted into me".

[54:12] For as men of this kind are hard to be captured, so the opposite sort are a ready prey, and are easily thrown down.

[54:13] As was the case of the Jews at that time; for after having heard and believed, they again turned out of the way.

[54:14] Christ therefore desiring to deepen their faith that it might not be merely superficial, diggeth into their souls by more striking words.

[54:15] For it was the part of believers to endure even reproofs, but they immediately were wroth.

[54:16] But how doth He this? He first telleth them, "If ye continue in My word, ye are My disciples indeed: and the truth shall make you free".

[54:17] All but saying, "I am about to make a deep incision, but be not ye moved"; or rather by these expressions He allayed the pride of their imagination.

[54:18] "Shall make you free": from what, tell me? From your sins.

[54:19] What then say those boasters?  Ver.

[54:20] "We be Abraham's seed, and were never in bondage to any man".

[54:21] Immediately their imagination dropped, and this happened from their having been fluttered about worldly things.

[54:22] "If ye continue in My word," was the expression of One declaring what was in their heart, and knowing that they had indeed believed, but had not continued.

[54:23] And He promiseth a great thing, that they should become His disciples.

[54:24] For since some had gone away from Him before this, alluding to them He saith, "If ye continue," because they also had heard and believed, and departed because they could not continue.

[54:25] "For many of His disciples went back, and walked no more openly with Him".

[54:26] ( c.

[54:27] vi.

[54:28] )  "Ye shall know the truth," that is, "shall know Me, for I am the truth.

[54:29] All the Jewish matters were types, but ye shall know the truth from Me, and it shall free you from your sins".

[54:30] As to those others He said, "Ye shall die in your sins," so to these He saith, "shall make you free".

[54:31] He said not, "I will deliver you from bondage," this He allowed them to conjecture.

[54:32] What then said they?  "We be Abraham's seed, and were never in bondage to any man".

[54:33] And yet if they must needs have been vexed, it might have been expected that they would have been so at the former part of His speech, at His having said, "Ye shall know the truth"; and that they would have replied, "What! do we not now know the truth? Is then the Law and our knowledge a lie?" But they cared for none of these things, they are grieved at worldly things, and these were their notions of bondage.

[54:34] And certainly even now, there are many who feel shame at indifferent matters, and at this kind of bondage, but who feel none for the bondage of sin, and who would rather be called servants to this latter kind of bondage ten thousand times, than once to the former.

[54:35] Such were these men, and they did not even know of any other bondage, and they say, "Bondsmen callest thou those who are of the race of Abraham, the nobly born, who therefore ought not to be called bondsmen? For, saith one, we were never in bondage to any man".

[54:36] Such are the boastings of the Jews.

[54:37] "We are the seed of Abraham," "we are Israelites".

[54:38] They never mention their own righteous deeds.

[54:39] Wherefore John cried out to them, saying, "Think not to say that we have Abraham to our father".

[54:40] ( Matt.

[54:41] iii.

[54:42] ) And why did not Christ confute them, for they had often been in bondage to the Egyptians, Babylonians, and many others? Because His words were not to gain honor for Himself, but for their salvation, for their benefit, and toward this object He was pressing.

[54:43] For He might have spoken of the four hundred years, He might have spoken of the seventy, He might have spoken of the years of bondage during the time of the Judges, at one time twenty, at another two, at another seven; He might have said that they had never ceased being in bondage.

[54:44] But He desired not to show that they were slaves of men, but that they were slaves of sin, which is the most grievous slavery, from which God alone can deliver; for to forgive sins belongeth to none other.

[54:45] And this too they allowed.

[54:46] Since then they confessed that this was the work of God, He bringeth them to this point, and saith,  Ver.

[54:47] "Whosoever committeth sin is the servant of sin".

[54:48] Showing that this is the freedom of which He speaketh, the freedom from this service.

[54:49] Ver.

[54:50] "The servant abideth not in the house, but the Son abideth forever".

[54:51] Gently too from this He casts down the things of the Law, alluding to former times.

[54:52] For that they may not run back to them and say, "We have the sacrifices which Moses commanded, they are able to deliver us," He addeth these words, since otherwise what connection would the saying have? For "all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God, being justified freely by His grace" ( Rom.

[54:53] iii.

[54:54] ,  ), even the priests themselves.

[54:55] Wherefore Paul also saith of the priest, that "he ought as for the people so also for himself to offer for sins, for that he also is compassed about with infirmity".

[54:56] ( Heb.

[54:57] v.

[54:58] ,.

[54:59] ) And this is signified by His saying, "The servant abideth not in the house".

[54:60] Here also He showeth His equal honor with the Father, and the difference between slave and free.

[54:61] For the parable has this meaning, that is, "the servant hath no power," this is the meaning of "abideth not".

[54:62] But why when speaking of sins doth He mention a "house"? It is to show that as a master hath power over his house, so He over all.

[54:63] And the, "abideth not," is this,"hath not power to grant favors, as not being master of the house"; but the Son is master of the house.

[54:64] For this is the, "abideth forever," by a metaphor drawn from human things.

[54:65] That they may not say, "who art thou?" "All is Mine, (He saith,) for I am the Son, and dwell in My Father's house," calling by the name of "house" His power.

[54:66] As in another place He calleth the Kingdom His Father's house, "In My Father's house are many mansions".

[54:67] ( c.

[54:68] xiv.

[54:69] ) For since the discourse was of freedom and bondage, He with reason used this metaphor, telling them that they had no power to set free.

[54:70] Ver.

[54:71] "If the Son therefore shall make you free".

[54:72] Seest thou the consubstantiality of the Son with the Father, and how He declareth that He hath the same power as the Father? "If the Son make you free, no man afterwards gain-sayeth, but ye have firm freedom".

[54:73] For "it is God that justifieth, who is He that condemneth?" ( Rom.

[54:74] viii.

[54:75] ,.

[54:76] ) Here He showeth that He Himself is pure from sin, and alludeth to that freedom which reached only to a name; this even men give, but that God alone.

[54:77] And so he persuaded them not to be ashamed at this slavery, but at that of sin.

[54:78] And desiring to show that they were not slaves, except by repudiating that liberty, He the more showeth them to be slaves by saying,  "Ye shall be free indeed".

[54:79] This is the expression of one declaring that this freedom was not real.

[54:80] Then, that they might not say, "We have no sin," (for it was probable that they would say so,) observe how He bringeth them beneath this imputation.

[54:81] For omitting to convict all their life, He bringeth forward that which they had in hand, which they yet desired to do, and saith,  Ver.

[54:82] "I know that ye are Abraham's seed but ye seek to kill Me".

[54:83] Gently and by little doth He expel them from that relationship, teaching them not to be high-minded because of it.

[54:84] For as freedom and bondage depend on men's actions, so also doth relationship.

[54:85] He said not directly, "Ye are not the seed of Abraham, ye the murderers of the righteous"; but for a while He even goeth along with them, and saith, "I know that ye are Abraham's seed".

[54:86] Yet this is not the matter in question, and during the remainder of this speech He useth greater vehemence.

[54:87] For we may for the most part observe, that when He is about to work any great thing, after He hath wrought it, He useth greater boldness of speech, as though the testimony from His works shut men's mouths.

[54:88] "But ye seek to kill Me".

[54:89] "What of that," saith some one, "if they sought to do so justly".

[54:90] But this was not so either; wherefore also He puts the reason;  "Because My word hath no place in you".

[54:91] "How then was it," saith some one, "that they believed on Him?" As I before said, they changed again.

[54:92] On which account He touched them sharply.

[54:93] "If ye boast the relationship of Abraham ye ought also to show forth his life".

[54:94] And He said not, "Ye do not contain my words," but, "My word hath no place in you," thus declaring the sublimity of His doctrines.

[54:95] Yet not for this ought they to have slain, but rather to have honored and waited on Him so as to learn.

[54:96] "But what," saith some one, "if thou speakest these things of thyself?" On this account He added,  Ver.

[54:97] "I speak that which I have seen with My Father, and ye do that which ye have heard from your father".

[54:98] "As," He saith, "I both by My words and by the truth declare the Father, so also do ye by your actions (declare yours).

[54:99] For I have not only the same Substance, but also the same Truth with the Father".

[54:100] Ver.

[54:101] ,.

[54:102] "They said unto Him, Abraham is our father.

[54:103] Jesus saith unto them, If ye had Abraham to your father, ye would do the works of Abraham.

[54:104] But now ye seek to kill Me".

[54:105] He here repeatedly handleth their murderous intention, and maketh mention of Abraham.

[54:106] And this He doth desiring to draw off their attention from this relationship, and to take away their excessive boasting, and also to persuade them no longer to rest their hopes of salvation in Abraham, nor in the relationship which is according to nature, but in that which is according to the will.

[54:107] For what hindered their coming to Christ was this, their deeming that relationship to be sufficient for them to salvation.

[54:108] But what is the "truth" of which He speaketh? That He is equal with the Father.

[54:109] For it was on this account that the Jews sought to slay Him; and He saith,  "Ye seek to kill Me because I have told you the truth, which I have heard of My Father".

[54:110] To show that these things are not opposed to the Father, He again betaketh Himself to Him.

[54:111] They say unto Him,  Ver.

[54:112] "We be not born of fornication, we have one Father, even God".

[54:113] "What sayest thou? Ye have God for your Father, and do ye blame Christ for asserting this?" Seest thou that He said that God was His Father in a special manner? When therefore He had cast them out of their relationship to Abraham, having nothing to reply, they dare a greater thing, and betake themselves to God.

[54:114] But from this honor also He expelleth them, saying,  Ver.

[54:115] -.

[54:116] "If God were your Father, ye would love Me; for I proceeded forth and came from God; neither came I of Myself, but He sent Me.

[54:117] Why do ye not understand My speech? Even because ye cannot hear My word.

[54:118] Ye are of your father the devil, and the lusts of your father ye will do: he was a murderer from the beginning, and abode not in the truth: when he speaketh a lie, he speaketh of his own".

[54:119] He had driven them out of their relationship to Abraham, and when they dared greater things, He then addeth a blow, telling them that they not only are not Abraham's children, but that they are even children of the devil, and inflicting a wound which might counterbalance their shamelessness; nor doth He leave it unsupported, but establisheth it by proofs.

[54:120] "For," He saith, "to murder belongeth to the wickedness of the devil".

[54:121] And He said not merely, "ye do his works," but, "ye do his lusts," showing that both he and they hold to murder, and that envy was the cause.

[54:122] For the devil destroyed Adam, not because he had any charge against him, but only from envy.

[54:123] To this also He alludeth here.

[54:124] "And abode not in the truth".

[54:125] That is, in the right life.

[54:126] For since they continually accused Him of not being from God, He telleth them that this also is from thence.

[54:127] For the devil first was the father of a lie, when he said, "In the day that ye eat thereof your eyes shall be opened" ( Gen.

[54:128] iii.

[54:129] ), and he first used it.

[54:130] For men use a lie not as a thing proper, but alien to their nature, but he as proper.

[54:131] Ver.

[54:132] "And because I tell you the truth, ye believe Me not".

[54:133] What kind of consequence is this? "Having no charge against Me, ye desire to kill Me.

[54:134] For because ye are enemies of the truth, therefore ye persecute Me.

[54:135] Since had this not been the reason, ye would have named your charge".

[54:136] Wherefore He added,  Ver.

[54:137] "Which of you convinceth Me of sin?"  Then they said, "We be not born of fornication".

[54:138] Yet in fact many of them were born of fornication, for they practiced unbefitting unions.

[54:139] Still He doth not convict them of this, but setteth Himself to the other point.

[54:140] For when He hath proved them to be, not of God, but of the devil, by all these signs, (for to do murder is of the devil, and to lie is of the devil, both which ye do,) then He showeth that to love is the sign of being of God.

[54:141] "Why do ye not understand My speech?" Since they were always doubting, saying, "What is it that he saith, 'Whither I go ye cannot come'?" therefore He telleth them, "Ye do not understand My speech," "because ye have not the word of God.

[54:142] And this cometh to you, because that your understanding is groveling, and because what is Mine is far too great for you".

[54:143] But what if they could not understand? Not to be able here means not to be willing; for "ye have trained yourselves to be mean, to imagine nothing great".

[54:144] Because they said that they persecuted Him as being themselves zealous for God, on this account He everywhere striveth to show that to persecute Him is the act of those who hate God, but that, on the contrary, to love Him is the act of those who know God.

[54:145] "We have one Father, even God".

[54:146] On this ground they pride themselves, on their honor not their righteous deeds.

[54:147] "Therefore your not believing is no proof that I am an enemy to God, but your unbelief is a sign that you do not know God.

[54:148] And the reason is, from your being willing to lie and to do the works of the devil.

[54:149] But this is the effect of meanness of soul; (as the Apostle saith, 'For whereas there is among you envying and strife, are ye not carnal?') (  Cor.

[54:150] iii.

[54:151] ) And why is it that ye cannot ? Because ye will to do the lusts of your father, ye are eager, ye are ambitious (to do them)".

[54:152] Seest thou that "ye cannot" express a want of will? For "this did not Abraham".

[54:153] "What are his works? Gentleness, meekness, obedience.

[54:154] But ye set yourselves on the contrary part, being hard and cruel".

[54:155] But how came it into their thoughts to betake themselves to God? He had shown them unworthy of Abraham; desiring therefore to escape this charge, they mounted higher.

[54:156] For when He reproached them with murder, they said this, making it, as it were, a kind of excuse for themselves that they were avenging God.

[54:157] Therefore He showeth that this very thing is the act of men opposing God.

[54:158] And the, "I came forth," showeth that He was from thence.

[54:159] He saith, "I came forth," alluding to His arrival among us.

[54:160] But since they would probably say to Him, "Thou speaketh certain things strange and new," He telleth them that He was come from God.

[54:161] "And therefore with good reason ye hear them not, because ye are of the devil.

[54:162] For on what account would ye kill Me? What charge have ye to bring against Me? If there be none, why do ye not believe Me?" Thus then having proved them to be of the devil by their lying and their murder, He showeth them also to be alien from Abraham and from God, both because they hated One who had done no wrong, and because they would not hear His word; and in every way He proveth that He was not opposed to God, and that it was not on this account that they refused to believe, but because they were aliens from God.

[54:163] For when One who had done no sin, who said that He came from God and was sent of God, who spake the truth, and so spake it as to challenge all to the proof, after this was not believed, it is clear that He was not believed because of their being carnal.

[54:164] Since sins do use, yea they do use to debase a soul.

[54:165] Wherefore It saith, "Seeing ye are become dull of hearing".

[54:166] ( Heb.

[54:167] v.

[54:168] ) For when a man cannot despise earthly things, how shall he ever be wise concerning heavenly things?   Wherefore, I exhort you, use we every means that our life may be righteous, that our minds may be cleansed, so that no filthiness be a hindrance to us; kindle for yourselves the light of knowledge, and sow not among thorns.

[54:169] For how shall one who knows not that covetousness is an evil, ever know the greater good? how shall one who refrains not from these earthly things ever hold fast to those heavenly? It is good to take by violence, not the things that perish, but the Kingdom of heaven.

[54:170] "The violent," it saith, "take it by force".

[54:171] ( Matt.

[54:172] xi.

[54:173] ) It is then not possible to attain to it by sluggishness, but by zeal.

[54:174] But what meaneth "the violent"? There is need of much violence, (for strait is the way,) there is need of a youthful soul and a noble.

[54:175] Plunderers desire to outstrip all other, they look to nothing, neither to conviction, nor accusation, nor punishment, but are given up to one thing only, the getting hold of what they desire to seize, and they run past all that are before them in the way.

[54:176] Seize we then the Kingdom of heaven, for here to seize is no fault but rather praise, and the fault is the not seizing.

[54:177] Here our wealth comes not from another's loss.

[54:178] Haste we then to seize it.

[54:179] Should passion disquiet us, should lust disquiet us, let us do violence to our nature, let us become more gentle, let us labor a little, that we may rest forever.

[54:180] Seize not thou gold, but seize that wealth which showeth gold to be but mud.

[54:181] For tell me, if lead and gold were laid before thee, which wouldest thou take? Is it not clear that thou wouldest take the gold? Dost thou then, where one who seizes is punished, prefer that which is the more valuable, but where one who seizes is honored, give up what is the more valuable? If there were punishment in both cases, wouldest thou not rather aim at this latter ? But in this case there is nothing like punishment, but even blessedness.

[54:182] And, "How," saith some one, "may one seize it?" Cast away the things which thou hast already in thy hands; for so long as thou graspest them thou wilt not be able to seize the other.

[54:183] For consider, I pray you, a man with his hands full of silver, will he be able, as long as he retains it, to seize on gold, unless he first cast away the silver, and be free? Because he that seizes a thing must be well-girt so as not to be detained.

[54:184] And even now there are adverse powers running down against us to rob us, but let us fly them, let us fly them, trailing after us nothing that may give a hold, let us cut asunder the cords, let us strip ourselves of the things of earth.

[54:185] What need of silken garments? How long shall we be unrolling this mockery? How long shall we be burying gold? I desired to cease from always saying these things, but ye will not suffer me, continually supplying me with occasions and arguments.

[54:186] But now at least let us desist, that having instructed others by our lives, we may obtain the promised good things, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom and with whom to the Father and the Holy Ghost be glory, now and ever and world without end, Amen.

[55:1] Homily LV.

[55:2] John viii.

[55:3] ,  "Then answered the Jews, and said unto Him, Say we not well that thou art a Samaritan, and hast a devil? Jesus answered, I have not a devil; but I honor My Father".

[55:4] A shameless and a forward thing is wickedness, and when it ought to hide itself, then is it the fiercer.

[55:5] As was the case with the Jews.

[55:6] For when they ought to have been pricked by what was said, admiring the boldness and conclusiveness of the words, they even insult Him, calling Him a Samaritan, and saying that He had a devil, and they ask, "Said we not well that thou art a Samaritan, and hast a devil?" Because when He uttereth anything sublime, this is thought among the very senseless to be madness.

[55:7] Yet nowhere before did the Evangelist say that they called Him "a Samaritan"; but from this expression it is probable that this had been often asserted by them.

[55:8] "Thou hast a devil," saith some one.

[55:9] Who is it that hath a devil? He that honoreth God, or he that insulteth Him that honoreth Him? What then saith Christ, who is very meekness and gentleness? "I have not a devil, but I honor Him that sent me".

[55:10] Where there was need to instruct them, to pull down their excessive insolence, to teach them not to be proud because of Abraham, He was vehement; but when it was needful that He being insulted should bear it, He used much gentleness.

[55:11] When they said, "We have God and Abraham for our Father," He touched them sharply; but when they called Him a demoniac, He spake submissively, thus teaching us to avenge insults offered to God, but to overlook such as are offered to ourselves.

[55:12] Ver.

[55:13] "I seek not Mine own glory".

[55:14] "These things," He saith, "I have spoken to show that it becometh not you, being murderers, to call God your Father; so that I have spoken them through honor for Him, and for His sake do I hear these reproaches, and for His sake do ye dishonor Me.

[55:15] Yet I care not for this insolence ; to Him, for whose sake I now hear these things, ye owe an account of your words.

[55:16] For 'I seek not Mine own glory.

[55:17] ' Wherefore I omit to punish you, and betake Myself to exhortation, and counsel you so to act, that ye shall not only escape punishment, but also attain eternal life".

[55:18] Ver.

[55:19] "Verily, verily, I say unto you, If a man keep My saying, he shall never see death".

[55:20] Here He speaketh not of faith only, but of a pure life.

[55:21] Above He said, "shall have everlasting life," but here, "shall not see death".

[55:22] ( c.

[55:23] vi.

[55:24] ) At the same time He hinteth to them that they could do nothing against Him, for if the man that should keep His saying should not die, much less should He Himself.

[55:25] At least they understood it so, and said to Him,  Ver.

[55:26] "Now we know that thou hast a devil; Abraham is dead, and the Prophets are dead".

[55:27] That is, "they who heard the word of God are dead, and shall they who have heard thine not die?"  Ver.

[55:28] "Art thou greater than our father Abraham?"  Alas for their vainglory! Again do they betake themselves to his relationship.

[55:29] Yet it would have been suitable to say, "Art thou greater than God? or they who have heard thee than Abraham?" But they say not this, because they thought that He was even less than Abraham.

[55:30] At first, therefore, He showed that they were murderers, and so led them away from the relationship; but when they persevered, He contrived this in another way, showing that they labored uselessly.

[55:31] And concerning the "death," He said nothing to them, neither did He reveal or tell them what kind of death He meant, but in the meantime He would have them believe, that He is greater than Abraham, that even by this He may put them to shame.

[55:32] "Certainly," He saith, "were I a common man I ought not to die, having done no wrong; but when I speak the truth, and have no sin, am sent from God, and am greater than Abraham, are ye not mad, do ye not labor in vain when ye attempt to kill Me?" What then is their reply? "Now we know that thou hast a devil".

[55:33] Not so spake the woman of Samaria.

[55:34] She said not to Him, "Thou hast a devil"; but only, "Art thou greater than our father Jacob?" ( c.

[55:35] iv.

[55:36] ) For these men were insolent and accursed, while she desired to learn; wherefore she doubted and answered with proper moderation, and called Him, "Lord".

[55:37] For one who promised far greater things, and who was worthy of credit, ought not to have been insulted, but even admired; yet these men said that He had a devil.

[55:38] Those expressions of the Samaritan woman were those of one in doubt; these were the words of men unbelieving and perverse.

[55:39] "Art thou greater than our father Abraham?" so that this (which He had said) maketh Him to be greater than Abraham.

[55:40] "When therefore ye have seen Him lifted up, ye shall confess that He is greater".

[55:41] On this account He said, "When ye have lifted Me up, ye shall know that I Am".

[55:42] ( Ver.

[55:43] ) And observe His wisdom.

[55:44] Having first rent them away from Abraham's kindred, He showeth that He is greater than Abraham, that so He may be seen to be very exceedingly greater than the Prophets also.

[55:45] Indeed it was because they continually called Him a prophet that He said, "My word hath no place in you".

[55:46] ( Ver.

[55:47] ) In that other place He declared that He raiseth the dead, but here He saith, "He that believeth shall never see death," which was a much greater thing than not to allow believers to be holden, by death.

[55:48] Wherefore the Jews were the more enraged.

[55:49] What then say they?  "Whom makest thou thyself?"  And this too in an insulting manner.

[55:50] "Thou art taking somewhat upon thyself," saith one of them.

[55:51] To this then Christ replieth;  Ver.

[55:52] "If I honor Myself, My honor is nothing".

[55:53] What say the heretics here? That He heard the question, "Art thou greater than our father Abraham?" and dared not to say to them, "Yea, I am greater," but did so in a covert manner.

[55:54] What then? Is His honor "nothing"? With respect to them it is nothing.

[55:55] And as He said, "My witness is not true" ( c.

[55:56] v.

[55:57] ), with reference to the opinion they would form of it, so also doth He speak here.

[55:58] "There is One that honoreth Me".

[55:59] And wherefore said He not, "The Father that sent Me," as He did before, but,  "Of whom ye say that He is your God".

[55:60] Ver.

[55:61] "Yet ye have not known Him".

[55:62] Because He desired to show that they not only knew not His Father, but that they knew not God.

[55:63] "But I know Him".

[55:64] "So that to say, 'I know Him,' is not a boast, while to say, 'I know Him not,' would be a falsehood; but ye when ye say that ye know Him, lie; as then ye, when ye say that ye know Him, lie, so also should I, were I to say that I know Him not".

[55:65] "If I honor Myself".

[55:66] Since they said, "Whom makest thou thyself?" He replieth, "If I make (Myself anything,) My honor is nothing.

[55:67] As then I know Him exactly, so ye know Him not".

[55:68] And as in the case of Abraham, He did not take away their whole assertion, but said, "I know that ye are Abraham's seed," so as to make the charge against them heavier; thus here He doth not remove the whole, but what? "Whom ye say".

[55:69] By granting to them their boast of words, He increaseth the force of the accusation against them.

[55:70] How then do ye "not know Him"? "Because ye insult One who saith and doeth everything that He may be glorified, even when that One is sent from Him".

[55:71] This assertion is unsupported by testimony, but what follows serves to establish it.

[55:72] "And I keep His saying".

[55:73] Here they might, if at least they had anything to say, have refuted Him, for it was the strongest proof of His having been sent by God.

[55:74] Ver.

[55:75] "Your father Abraham rejoiced to see My day, and he saw it, and was glad".

[55:76] Again, He showeth that they were aliens from the race of Abraham, if they grieved at what he rejoiced in.

[55:77] "My day," seems to me to mean the day of the Crucifixion, which Abraham foreshowed typically by the offering of the ram and of Isaac.

[55:78] What do they reply?  Ver.

[55:79] "Thou art not yet forty years old, and hast Thou seen Abraham?"  So that we conclude that Christ was nearly forty.

[55:80] Ver.

[55:81] ,.

[55:82] "Jesus saith unto them, Before Abraham was, I Am.

[55:83] Then took they up stones to cast at Him".

[55:84] Seest thou how He proved Himself to be greater than Abraham? For the man who rejoiced to see His day, and made this an object of earnest desire, plainly did so because it was a day that should be for a benefit, and belonging to one greater than himself.

[55:85] Because they had said, "The carpenter's son" ( Matt.

[55:86] xiii.

[55:87] ), and imagined nothing more concerning Him, He leadeth them by degrees to an exalted notion of Him.

[55:88] Therefore when they heard the words, "Ye know not God," they were not grieved; but when they heard, "before Abraham was, I Am," as though the nobility of their descent were debased, they became furious, and would have stoned Him.

[55:89] "He saw My day, and was glad".

[55:90] He showeth, that not unwillingly He came to His Passion, since He praiseth him who was gladdened at the Cross.

[55:91] For this was the salvation of the world.

[55:92] But they cast stones at Him; so ready were they for murder, and they did this of their own accord, without enquiry.

[55:93] But wherefore said He not, "Before Abraham was, I was," instead of "I Am"? As the Father useth this expression, "I Am," so also doth Christ; for it signifieth continuous Being, irrespective of all time.

[55:94] On which account the expression seemed to them to be blasphemous.

[55:95] Now if they could not bear the comparison with Abraham, although this was but a trifling one, had He continually made Himself equal to the Father, would they ever have ceased casting stones at Him?  After this, again He fleeth as a man, and concealeth Himself, having laid before them sufficient instruction: and having accomplished His work, He went forth from the Temple, and departed to heal the blind, proving by His actions that He is before Abraham.

[55:96] But perhaps some one will say, "Why did He not paralyze their strength? So they would have believed".

[55:97] He healed the paralytic, yet they believed not; nay, He wrought ten thousand wonders; at the very Passion He cast them to the ground, and darkened their eyes, yet they believed not; and how would they have believed if He had paralyzed their strength? There is nothing worse than a soul hardened in desperation; though it see signs and wonders, it still perseveres in retaining the same shamelessness.

[55:98] Thus Pharaoh, who received ten thousand strokes, was sobered only while being punished, and continued of this character until the last day of his life, pursuing those whom he had let go.

[55:99] Wherefore Paul continually saith, "Lest any of you be hardened by the deceitfulness of sin".

[55:100] ( Heb.

[55:101] iii.

[55:102] ) For as the callosities of the body, when formed, become dead, and possess no sensation; so the soul, when it is occupied by many passions, becomes dead to virtue; and apply what you will to it, it gets no perception of the matter, but whether you threaten punishment or anything else, continues insensible.

[55:103] Wherefore I beseech you, while we have hopes of salvation, while we can turn, to use every means to do so.

[55:104] For men who have become past feeling, are after that in the blind state of despairing pilots, who give up their vessel to the wind, and themselves contribute no assistance.

[55:105] Thus the envious man looks to one thing only, that is, to satisfy his lust, and though he be like to be punished or even slain, still he is possessed solely by that passion; and in like manner the intemperate and avaricious.

[55:106] But if the sovereignty of the passions be so great, much greater is that of virtue; if for them we despise death, much more for this; if they (sinners) regard not their own lives, much less ought we to do so in the cause of our salvation.

[55:107] For what shall we have to say, if when they who perish are so active about their own perdition, we for our own salvation manifest not even an equal activity, but ever continue wasting with envy? Nothing is worse than envy; to destroy another it destroys itself also.

[55:108] The eye of the envious wastes away in grief, he lives in a continual death, he deems all men, even those who have never wronged him, his enemies.

[55:109] He grieves that God is honored, he rejoices in what the devil rejoices in.

[55:110] Is any honored among men? This is not honor, envy him not.

[55:111] But is he honored by God? Strive and be thou like him.

[55:112] Thou wilt not? Why then dost thou destroy thyself too? Why castest thou away what thou hast? Canst thou not be like unto him, nor gain any good thing? Why then dost thou besides this take for thyself evil, when thou oughtest to rejoice with him, that so even if thou be not able to share his toils, thou mayest profit by rejoicing with Him? For often even the will is able to effect great good.

[55:113] At least Ezekiel saith, that the Moabites were punished because they rejoiced over the Israelites, and that certain others were saved because they mourned over the misfortunes of their neighbors.

[55:114] ( Ezek.

[55:115] xxv.

[55:116] ) Now if there be any comfort for those who mourn over the woes of others, much more for those who rejoice at the honors of others.

[55:117] He charged the Moabites with having exulted over the Israelites, yet it was God that punished them; but not even when He punisheth will He have us rejoice over those that are punished.

[55:118] For it is not His wish to punish them.

[55:119] Now if we must condole with those who are punished, much more must we avoid envying those who are honored.

[55:120] Thus, for example, Corah and Dathan perished with their company, making those whom they envied brighter, and giving themselves up to punishment.

[55:121] For a venomous beast is envy, an unclean beast, a deliberate vice which admits not of pardon, a wickedness stripped of excuse, the cause and mother of all evils.

[55:122] Wherefore let us pluck it up by the roots, that we may be freed from evil here, and may obtain blessings hereafter; through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, by whom and with whom, to the Father and the Holy Ghost, be glory now and ever and world without end, Amen.

[56:1] Homily LVI.

[56:2] John ix.

[56:3] ,  "And as Jesus passed by, He saw a man which was blind from his birth.

[56:4] And His disciples asked Him, saying, Master, who did sin, this man, or his parents, that he was born blind?"   "And as Jesus passed by, He saw a man which was blind from his birth".

[56:5] Being full of love for man, and caring for our salvation, and desiring to stop the mouths of the foolish, He omitteth nothing of His own part, though there be none to give heed.

[56:6] And the Prophet knowing this saith, "That Thou mightest be justified when Thou speakest, and be clear when Thou art judged".

[56:7] ( Ps.

[56:8] li.

[56:9] ) Wherefore here, when they would not receive His sublime sayings, but said that He had a devil, and attempted to kill Him, He went forth from the Temple, and healed the blind, mitigating their rage by His absence, and by working the miracle softening their hardness and cruelty, and establishing His assertions.

[56:10] And He worketh a miracle which was no common one, but one which took place then for the first time.

[56:11] "Since the world began," saith he who was healed, "was it not heard that any man opened the eyes of one that was born blind".

[56:12] ( Ver.

[56:13] ) Some have, perhaps, opened the eyes of the blind, but of one born blind never.

[56:14] And that on going out of the Temple, He proceeded intentionally to the work, is clear from this; it was He who saw the blind man, not the blind man who came to Him; and so earnestly did He look upon him, that even His disciples perceived it.

[56:15] From this, at least, they came to question Him; for when they saw Him earnestly regarding the man, they asked Him, saying, "Who did sin, this man, or his parents?" A mistaken question, for how could he sin before he was born? and how, if his parents had sinned, would he have been punished? Whence then came they to put this question? Before, when He healed the paralytic, He said, "Behold, thou art made whole, sin no more".

[56:16] ( c.

[56:17] v.

[56:18] ) They therefore, having understood that he was palsied on account of sin, said, "Well, that other was palsied because of his sins; but concerning this man, what wouldest Thou say? hath he sinned? It is not possible to say so, for he is blind from his birth.

[56:19] Have his parents sinned? Neither can one say this, for the child suffers not punishment for the father".

[56:20] As therefore when we see a child evil entreated, we exclaim, "What can one say of this? what has the child done?" not as asking a question, but as being perplexed, so the disciples spake here, not so much asking for information, as being in perplexity.

[56:21] What then saith Christ?  Ver.

[56:22] "Neither hath this man sinned, nor his parents".

[56:23] This He saith not as acquitting them of sins, for He saith not simply, "Neither hath this man sinned, nor his parents," but addeth, "that he should have been born blind —but that the Son of God should be glorified in him".

[56:24] "For both this man hath sinned and his parents, but his blindness proceedeth not from that".

[56:25] And this He said, not signifying that though this man indeed was not in such case, yet that others had been made blind from such a cause, the sins of their parents, since it cannot be that when one sinneth another should be punished.

[56:26] For if we allow this, we must also allow that he sinned before his birth.

[56:27] As therefore when He declared, "neither hath this man sinned," He said not that it is possible to sin from one's very birth, and be punished for it; so when He said, "nor his parents," He said not that one may be punished for his parents' sake.

[56:28] This supposition He re moveth by the mouth of Ezekiel; "As I live saith the Lord, this proverb shall not be, that is used, The fathers have eaten sour grapes, and the children's teeth are set on edge".

[56:29] ( Ezek.

[56:30] xviii.

[56:31] ,.

[56:32] ) And Moses saith, "The father shall not die for the child, neither shall the child die for the father".

[56:33] ( Deut.

[56:34] xxiv.

[56:35] ) And of a certain king Scripture saith, that for this very reason he did not this thing, observing the law of Moses.

[56:36] But if any one argue, "How then is it said, 'Who visiteth the sins of the parents upon the children unto the third and fourth generation'?" ( Deut.

[56:37] v.

[56:38] ); we should make this answer, that the assertion is not universal, but that it is spoken with reference to certain who came out of Egypt.

[56:39] And its meaning is of this kind; "Since these who have come out of Egypt, after signs and wonders, have become worse than their forefathers who saw none of these things, they shall suffer," It saith, "the same that those others suffered, since they have dared the same crimes".

[56:40] And that it was spoken of those men, any one who will give attention to the passage will more certainly know.

[56:41] Wherefore then was he born blind?  "That the glory of God should be made manifest," He saith.

[56:42] Lo, here again is another difficulty, if without this man's punishment, it was not possible that the glory of God should be shown.

[56:43] Certainly it is not said that it was impossible, for it was possible, but, "that it might be manifested even in this man".

[56:44] "What," saith some one, "did he suffer wrong for the glory of God?" What wrong, tell me? For what if God had never willed to produce him at all? But I assert that he even received benefit from his blindness: since he recovered the sight of the eyes within.

[56:45] What were the Jews profited by their eyes? They incurred the heavier punishment, being blinded even while they saw.

[56:46] And what injury had this man by his blindness? For by means of it he recovered sight.

[56:47] As then the evils of the present life are not evils, so neither are the good things good; sin alone is an evil, but blindness is not an evil.

[56:48] And He who had brought this man from not being into being, had also power to leave him as he was.

[56:49] But some say, that this conjunction is not at all expressive of cause, but relates to the consequence of the miracle; as when He saith, "For judgment I am come into this world, that they which see not might see, and that they which see might be made blind" ( ver.

[56:50] ); and yet it was not for this He came, that those who saw might be made blind.

[56:51] And again Paul, "Because that which may be known of God is manifested in them, that they may be without excuse" ( Rom.

[56:52] i.

[56:53] ,  ); yet He showed it not unto them for this, that they might be deprived of excuse, but that they might obtain excuse.

[56:54] And again in another place, "The Law entered, that the offense might abound" ( Rom.

[56:55] v.

[56:56] ); yet it was not for this that it entered, but that sin might be checked.

[56:57] Seest thou everywhere that the conjunction relates to the consequence? For as some excellent architect may build part of a house, and leave the rest unfinished, so that to those who believe not he may prove, by means of that remnant, that he is author of the whole; so also God joineth together and completeth our body, as it were a house decayed, healing the withered hand, bracing the palsied limbs, straightening the lame, cleansing the lepers, raising up the sick, making sound the crippled, recalling the dead from death, opening the eyes that were closed, or adding them where before they were not; all which things, being blemishes arising from the infirmity of our nature, He by correcting showed His power.

[56:58] But when He said, "That the glory of God might be manifested," He spake of Himself, not of the Father; His glory was already manifest.

[56:59] For since they had heard that God made man, taking the dust of the earth, so also Christ made clay.

[56:60] To have said, "I am He who took the dust of the earth, and made man," would have seemed a hard thing to His hearers; but this when shown by actual working, no longer stood in their way.

[56:61] So that He by taking earth, and mixing it with spittle, showed forth His hidden glory; for no small glory was it that He should be deemed the Architect of the creation.

[56:62] And after this the rest also followed; from the part, the whole was proved, since the belief of the greater also confirmed the less.

[56:63] For man is more honorable than any created thing, and of our members the most honorable is the eye.

[56:64] This is the cause that He fashioned the eyes, not in a common manner, but in the way that He did.

[56:65] For though that member be small in size, yet it is more necessary than any part of the body.

[56:66] And this Paul showed when he said, "If the ear shall say, Because I am not the eye, I am not of the body; is it therefore not of the body?" (  Cor.

[56:67] xii.

[56:68] ) For all indeed that is in us is a manifestation of the wisdom of God, but much more the eye; this it is that guides the whole body, this gives beauty to it all, this adorns the countenance, this is the light of all the limbs.

[56:69] What the sun is in the world, that the eye is in the body; quench the sun, and you destroy and confound all things; quench the eyes, and the feet, the hands, the soul, are useless.

[56:70] When these are disabled, even knowledge is gone, since by means of these we know God.

[56:71] "For the invisible things of Him from the creation of the world are clearly seen, being understood by the things that are made".

[56:72] ( Rom.

[56:73] i.

[56:74] ) Wherefore the eye is not only a light to the body, but beyond the body to the soul also.

[56:75] On which account it is established as in a royal fortress, obtaining the higher condition, and presiding over the other senses.

[56:76] This then Christ forms.

[56:77] And that thou mayest not deem that He needeth matter when He worketh, and that thou mayest learn that He had not need at all of clay, (for He who brought into being the greater existences when as yet they were not, would much more have made this without matter,) that I say thou mayest learn that He did not this through necessity, but to show that He was the Creator at the beginning, when He had spread on the clay He saith, "Go, wash," "that thou mayest know that I need not clay to create eyes, but that My glory may be manifested hereby".

[56:78] For to show that He spake of Himself when He said, "That the glory of God may be manifested," He added,  Ver.

[56:79] "I must work the works of Him that sent Me".

[56:80] That is, "I must manifest Myself, and do the things which may show that I do the same things with the Father"; not things "similar," but, "the same," an expression which marks greater unvaryingness, and which is used of those who do not differ ever so little.

[56:81] Who then after this will face Him, when he seeth that He hath the same power with the Father? For not only did He form or open eyes, but gave also the gift of sight, which is a proof that He also breathed in the soul.

[56:82] Since if that did not work, the eye, though perfected, could never see anything; so that He gave both the energy which is from the soul, and gave the member also possessing all things, both arteries and nerves and veins, and all things of which our body is composed.

[56:83] "I must work while it is day".

[56:84] What mean these words? To what conclusion do they lead? To an important one.

[56:85] For what He saith is of this kind.

[56:86] "While it is day, while men may believe on Me, while this life lasteth, I must work".

[56:87] "The night cometh," that is, futurity, "when no man can work".

[56:88] He said not, "when I cannot work," but, "when no man can work": that is, when there is no longer faith, nor labors, nor repentance.

[56:89] For to show that He calleth faith, a "work," when they say unto Him, "What shall we do, that we might work the works of God?" ( c.

[56:90] vi.

[56:91] ), He replieth, "This is the work of God, that ye believe on Him whom He hath sent".

[56:92] How then can no man work this work in the future world? Because there faith is not, but all, willingly, or unwillingly, will submit.

[56:93] For lest any one should say that He acted as He did from desire of honor, He showeth that He did all to spare them who had power to believe "here" only, but who could no longer "there" gain any good thing.
