[67:76] "Now is the judgment of this world, now shall the prince of this world be cast down".

[67:77] What connection hath this with, "I have glorified, and will glorify"? Much, and closely harmonizing.

[67:78] For when God saith, "I will glorify," He showeth the manner of the glorifying.

[67:79] What is it? That one should be cast down.

[67:80] But what is, "the judgment of this world"? It is as though He said, "there shall be a tribunal and a retribution".

[67:81] How and in what way? "He slew the first man, having found him guilty of sin, (for 'by sin death entered'— Rom.

[67:82] v.

[67:83] ;) but in Me this he found not.

[67:84] Why then did he spring upon Me and give Me over to death? Why did he put into the mind of Judas to destroy Me?" (Tell me not that it was God's dispensation, for this belongeth not to the devil, but His wisdom; for the present let the disposition of that evil one be enquired into.

[67:85] ) "How then is the world judged in Me?" It shall be said, as if a court of justice were sitting, to Satan, "Well, thou hast slain all men, because thou didst find them guilty of sin.

[67:86] But why didst thou slay Christ? Is it not clear that thou didst it wrongfully?" Therefore in Him the whole world shall be avenged.

[67:87] But, that this may be still more clear, I will make it plain by an exam ple.

[67:88] Suppose there is some cruel tyrant, bringing ten thousand evils on all those who fall into his hands.

[67:89] If such a one engaging with a king, or a king's son, slay him unjustly, his death will have power to get revenge for the others also.

[67:90] Suppose there is one who demands payment of his debtors, that he beats them and casts them into prison; then from the same recklessness that he leads to the same dungeon one who owes him nothing: such a man shall suffer punishment for what he hath done to the others.

[67:91] For that one shall destroy him.

[67:92] So also it is in the case of the Son; for of those things which the devil hath done against us, of these shall the penalty be required by means of what he hath dared against Christ.

[67:93] And to show that He implieth this, hear what He saith; "Now shall the prince of this world be cast down," "by My Death".

[67:94] Ver.

[67:95] "And I, if I be lifted up, will draw all men unto Me".

[67:96] That is, "even those of the Gentiles".

[67:97] And that no one may ask, "How shall he be cast down, if he is stronger even than Thou art?" He saith, "He is not stronger; how can he be stronger than One who draweth others to Him?" And He speaketh not of the Resurrection, but of what is more than the Resurrection, "I will draw all men to Myself".

[67:98] For had He said, "I shall rise again," it was not yet clear that they would believe; but by His saying, "they shall believe," both are proved at once, both this, and also that He must rise again.

[67:99] For had He continued dead, and been a mere man, no one would have believed.

[67:100] "I will draw all men to Myself".

[67:101] ( c.

[67:102] vi.

[67:103] ) How then said He that the Father draweth? Because when the Son draweth, the Father draweth also.

[67:104] He saith, "I will draw them," as though they were detained by a tyrant, and unable of themselves alone to approach Him, and to escape the hands of him who keepeth hold of them.

[67:105] In another place He calleth this "spoiling; no man can spoil a strong man's goods, except he first bind the strong man, and then spoil his goods".

[67:106] ( Matt.

[67:107] xii.

[67:108] ) This He said to prove His strength, and what there He calleth "spoiling," He hath here called "drawing".

[67:109] Knowing then these things, let us rouse ourselves, let us glorify God, not by our faith alone, but also by our life, since otherwise it would not be glory, but blasphemy.

[67:110] For God is not so much blasphemed by an impure heathen, as by a corrupt Christian.

[67:111] Wherefore I entreat you to do all that God may be glorified; for, "Woe," it saith, "to that servant by whom the Name of God is blasphemed," (and wherever there is a "woe," every punishment and vengeance straightway follows,) "but blessed is he by whom that Name is glorified".

[67:112] Let us then not be as in darkness, but avoid all sins, and especially those which tend to the hurt of others, since by these God is most blasphemed.

[67:113] What pardon shall we have, when, being commanded to give to others, we plunder the property of others? What shall be our hope of salvation? Thou art punished if thou hast not fed the hungry; but if thou hast even stripped one who was clothed, what sort of pardon shalt thou obtain? These things I will never desist from saying, for they who have not heard to-day perhaps will hear tomorrow, and they who take no heed to-morrow perhaps will be persuaded the next day; and even if any be so disposed as not to be persuaded, yet for us there will be no account to give of them at the Judgment.

[67:114] Our part we have fulfilled; may we never have cause to be ashamed of our words, nor you to hide your faces, but may all be able to stand with boldness before the judgment-seat of Christ, that we also may be able to rejoice over you, and to have some compensation of our own faults, in your being approved in Christ Jesus our Lord, with whom to the Father and the Holy Ghost be glory for ever, Amen.

[68:1] Homily LXVIII.

[68:2] John xii.

[68:3] "The people answered Him, We have heard out of the Law that Christ abideth for ever; and how sayest thou, The Son of Man must be lifted up? Who is this Son of Man?"   Deceit is a thing easily detected, and weak, though it be daubed outside with ten thousand colors.

[68:4] For as those who whitewash decayed walls, cannot by the plastering make them sound, so too those who lie are easily found out, as in fact was the case here with the Jews.

[68:5] For when Christ said to them, "If I be lifted up I will draw all men unto Me; We have heard," saith one of them, "out of the Law, that Christ remaineth forever; and how sayest thou, that the Son of Man must be lifted up? Who is this Son of Man?" Even they then knew that Christ was some Immortal One, and had life without end.

[68:6] And therefore they also knew what He meant; for often in Scripture the Passion and the Resurrection are mentioned in the same place.

[68:7] Thus Isaiah puts them together, saying, "He was led as a sheep to the slaughter" ( Isa.

[68:8] liii.

[68:9] ), and all that follows.

[68:10] David also in the second Psalm, and in many other places, connects these two things.

[68:11] The Patriarch too after saying, "He lay down, He couched as a lion," addeth, "And as a lion's whelp, who shall raise Him up?" ( Gen.

[68:12] xlix.

[68:13] ) He showeth at once the Passion and the Resurrection.

[68:14] But these men when they thought to silence Him, and to show that He was not the Christ, confessed by this very circumstance that the Christ remaineth forever.

[68:15] And observe their evil dealing; they said not, "We have heard that Christ neither suffereth nor is crucified," but that "He remaineth forever".

[68:16] Yet even this which has been mentioned, would have been no real objection, for the Passion was no hindrance to His Immortality.

[68:17] Hence we may see that they understood many of the doubtful points, and deliberately went wrong.

[68:18] For since He had before spoken about death, when they now heard in this place the, "be lifted up," they guessed that death was referred to.

[68:19] Then they said, "Who is this Son of Man?" This too they did deceitfully.

[68:20] "Think not, I pray," saith one, "that we say this concerning thee, assert not that we oppose thee through enmity, for, lo, we know not concerning whom thou speakest, and still we declare our opinion".

[68:21] What then doth Christ? To silence them, and to show that the Passion is no impediment to His enduring forever, He saith,  Ver.

[68:22] "Yet a little while," He saith, "is the light with you".

[68:23] Signifying that His death was a removal; for the light of the sun is not destroyed, but having retired for a while appears again.

[68:24] "Walk while ye have the light".

[68:25] Of what season doth He here speak? Of the whole present life, or of the time before the Crucifixion? I for my part think of both, for on account of His unspeakable lovingkindness, many even after the Crucifixion believed.

[68:26] And He speaketh these things to urge them on to the faith, as He also did before, saying, "Yet a little while I am with you".

[68:27] ( c.

[68:28] vii.

[68:29] )  "He that walketh in darkness knoweth not whither he goeth".

[68:30] How many things, for instance, even now do the Jews, without knowing what they do, but walking as though they were in darkness? They think that they are going the right way, when they are taking the contrary; keeping the Sabbath, respecting the Law and the observances about meats, yet knowing not whither they walk.

[68:31] Wherefore He said,  Ver.

[68:32] "Walk in the light, that ye may become children of the light".

[68:33] That is, "My children".

[68:34] Yet in the beginning the Evangelist saith, "Were born, not of bloods, nor of the will of the flesh, but of God" ( c.

[68:35] i.

[68:36] ); that is, of the Father; while here Himself is said to beget them; that thou mayest understand that the operation of the Father and the Son is One.

[68:37] "Jesus having spoken these things," departed from them, and did hide Himself.

[68:38] Why doth He now "hide Himself"? They took not up stones against Him, nor did they blaspheme Him in any such manner as before; why then did He hide Himself? Walking in men's hearts, He knew that their wrath was fierce, though they said nothing; He knew it boiling and murderous, and waited not till it issued into action, but hid Himself, to allay their ill-will.

[68:39] Observe how the Evangelist has alluded to this feeling; he has immediately added,  Ver.

[68:40] "Though He had done so many miracles, they believed not on Him".

[68:41] What "so many"? So many as the Evangelist hath omitted.

[68:42] And this is clear also from what follows.

[68:43] For when He had retired, and given in, and had come to them again, He speaketh with them in a lowly manner, saying, "He that believeth on Me, believeth not on Me, but on Him that sent Me".

[68:44] ( Ver.

[68:45] ) Observe what He doeth.

[68:46] He beginneth with humble and modest expressions, and betaketh Himself to the Father; then again He raiseth His language, and when He seeth that they are exasperated, He retireth; then He cometh to them again, and again beginneth with words of humility.

[68:47] And where hath He done this? Nay, where hath He not done it? See, for instance, what He saith at the beginning, "As I hear, I judge".

[68:48] ( c.

[68:49] v.

[68:50] ) Then in a loftier tone, "As the Father raiseth up the dead, and quickeneth them, so also the Son quickeneth whom He will" ( c.

[68:51] v.

[68:52] ); again, "I judge you not, there is another that judgeth".

[68:53] Then again He retireth.

[68:54] Then coming to Galilee, "Labor not," He saith, "for the meat that perisheth" ( c.

[68:55] vi.

[68:56] ); and after having said great things of Himself, that He came down from Heaven, that He giveth eternal life, He again withdraweth Himself.

[68:57] And He cometh in the Feast of Tabernacles also, and doth the same.

[68:58] And one may see Him continually thus varying His teaching, by His presence, by His absence, by lowly, by high discourses.

[68:59] Which He also did here.

[68:60] "Though He had done so many miracles," it saith, "they believed not on Him".

[68:61] Ver.

[68:62] "That the saying of Esaias might be fulfilled which he spake, Lord, who hath believed our report, and to whom hath the arm of the Lord been revealed?" And again,  Ver.

[68:63] –.

[68:64] "They could not believe," it saith, "because that Esaias said, Ye shall hear with your ears, and not understand.

[68:65] These things he said, when he saw His glory, and spake of Him".

[68:66] Here again observe, that the "because," and "spake," refer not to the cause of their unbelief, but to the event.

[68:67] For it was not "because" Isaiah spake, that they believed not; but because they were not about to believe, that he spake.

[68:68] Why then doth not the Evangelist express it so, instead of making the unbelief proceed from the prophecy, not the prophecy from the unbelief? And farther on he putteth this very thing more positively, saying, "Therefore they could not believe, because that Esaias said".

[68:69] He desires hence to establish by many proofs the unerring truth of Scripture, and that what Isaiah foretold fell not out otherwise, but as he said.

[68:70] For lest any one should say, "Wherefore did Christ come? Knew he not that they would give no heed to him?" he introduces the Prophets, who knew this also.

[68:71] But He came that they might have no excuse for their sin; for what things the Prophet foretold, he foretold as certainly to be; since if they were not certainly to be, he could not have foretold them; and they were certainly to be, because these men were incurable.

[68:72] And if, "they could not," is put, instead of, "they would not," do not marvel, for He saith also in another place, "He that is able to receive it, let him receive it".

[68:73] ( Matt.

[68:74] xix.

[68:75] ) So in many places He is wont to term choice, power.

[68:76] Again, "The world cannot hate you, but Me it hateth".

[68:77] ( c.

[68:78] vii.

[68:79] ) This one may even see observed in common conversation; as when a man saith, "I cannot love this or that person," calling the force of his will, power.

[68:80] And again, "this or that person cannot be a good man".

[68:81] And what saith the Prophet? "If the Ethiopian shall change his skin, or the leopard his spots, this people also shall be able to do good, having learned evil".

[68:82] ( Jer.

[68:83] xiii.

[68:84] , LXX.

[68:85] ) He saith not that the doing of virtue is impossible to them, but that because they will not, therefore they cannot.

[68:86] And by what he saith the Evangelist means, that it was impossible for the Prophet to lie; yet it was not on that account impossible that they should believe.

[68:87] For it was possible, even had they believed, that he should remain true; since he would not have prophesied these things if they had been about to believe.

[68:88] "Why then," saith some one, "did he not say so?" Because Scripture hath certain idiomatic phrases of this kind, and it is needful to make allowance for its laws.

[68:89] "The seethings he spake when he saw His glory".

[68:90] Whose? The Father's.

[68:91] How then doth John speak of the Son? and Paul of the Spirit? Not as confounding the Persons, but as showing that the Dignity is one, they say it.

[68:92] For that which is the Father's is the Son's also, and that which is the Son's is the Spirit's.

[68:93] Yet many things God spake by Angels, and no one saith, "as the Angel spake," but how? "as God spake".

[68:94] Since what hath been said by God through the ministry of Angels would be of God; yet not therefore is what is of God, of the Angels also.

[68:95] But in this place John saith that the words are the Spirit's.

[68:96] "And spake of Him".

[68:97] What spake he? "I saw the Lord sitting upon a high throne" ( Isa.

[68:98] vi.

[68:99] ), and what follows.

[68:100] Therefore he there calleth "glory," that vision, the smoke, the hearing unutterable Mysteries, the beholding the Seraphim, the lightning which leaped from the throne, against which those powers could not look.

[68:101] "And spake of Him".

[68:102] What said he? That he heard a voice, saying, "Whom shall I send? who shall go? And I said, Here am I, send me.

[68:103] And He said, Ye shall hear with your ears, and shall not understand, and seeing ye shall see, and not perceive".

[68:104] ( Isa.

[68:105] vi.

[68:106] ,.

[68:107] ) For,  Ver.

[68:108] "He hath blinded their eyes, and hardened their heart, lest they at any time should see with their eyes, and understand with their heart".

[68:109] Here again is another question, but it is not so if we rightly consider it.

[68:110] For as the sun dazzles the eyes of the weak, not by reason of its proper nature, so it is with those who give not heed to the words of God.

[68:111] Thus, in the case of Pharaoh, He is said to have hardened his heart, and so it is with those who are at all contentious against the words of God.

[68:112] This is a peculiar mode of speech in Scripture, as also the, "He gave them over unto a reprobate mind" ( Rom.

[68:113] i.

[68:114] ), and the, "He divided them to the nations," that is, allowed, permitted them to go.

[68:115] For the writer doth not here introduce God as Himself working these things, but showeth that they took place through the wickedness of others.

[68:116] For, when we are abandoned by God, we are given up to the devil, and when so given up, we suffer ten thousand dreadful things.

[68:117] To terrify the hearer, therefore, the writer saith, "He hardened," and "gave over".

[68:118] For to show that He doth not only not give us over, but doth not even leave us, except we will it, hear what He saith, "Do not your iniquities separate between Me and you?" ( Isa.

[68:119] lix.

[68:120] , LXX.

[68:121] ).

[68:122] And again, "They that go far away from Thee shall perish".

[68:123] ( Ps.

[68:124] lxxiii.

[68:125] , LXX.

[68:126] ) And Hosea saith, "Thou hast forgotten the law of thy God, and I will also forget thee" ( Hos.

[68:127] iv.

[68:128] , LXX.

[68:129] ); and He saith Himself also in the Gospels, "How often would I have gathered your children—and ye would not".

[68:130] ( Luke xiii.

[68:131] ) Esaias also again, "I came, and there was no man; I called, and there was none to hearken".

[68:132] ( Isa.

[68:133] l.

[68:134] , LXX.

[68:135] ) These things He saith, showing that we begin the desertion, and become the causes of our perdition; for God not only desireth not to leave or to punish us, but even when He punisheth, doth it unwillingly; "I will not," He saith, "the death of a sinner, so much as that he should turn and live".

[68:136] ( Ezek.

[68:137] xviii.

[68:138] , LXX.

[68:139] ) Christ also mourneth over the destruction of Jerusalem, as we also do over our friends.

[68:140] Knowing this, let us do all so as not to remove from God, but let us hold fast to the care of our souls, and to the love towards each other; let us not tear our own members, (for this is the act of men insane and beside themselves,) but the more we see any ill disposed, the more let us be kind to them.

[68:141] Since we often see many persons suffering in their bodies from difficult or incurable maladies, and cease not to apply remedies.

[68:142] What is worse than gout in foot or hand? Are we therefore to cut off the limbs? Not at all, but we use every means that the sufferer may enjoy some comfort, since we cannot get rid of the disease.

[68:143] This also let us do in the case of our brethren, and, even though they be diseased incurably, let us continue to tend them, and let us bear one another's burdens.

[68:144] So shall we fulfill the law of Christ, and obtain the promised good things, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, with whom to the Father and the Holy Ghost be glory for ever and ever, Amen.

[69:1] Homily LXIX.

[69:2] John xii.

[69:3] ,  "Nevertheless among the chief rulers also many believed on Him; but because of the Pharisees they did not confess Him, lest they should be put out of the synagogue: for they loved the praise of men more than the praise of God".

[69:4] It is necessary for us to avoid alike all the passions which corrupt the soul, but most especially those, which from themselves generate numerous sins.

[69:5] I mean such as the love of money.

[69:6] It is in truth of itself a dreadful malady, but it becomes much more grievous, because it is the root and mother of all mischiefs.

[69:7] Such also is vainglory.

[69:8] See, for instance, how these men were broken off from the faith through their love of honor.

[69:9] "Many," it saith, "of the chief rulers also believed on Him, but because of the Jews they did not confess Him, lest they should be put out of the synagogue".

[69:10] As He said also to them before, "How can ye believe which receive honor one of another, and seek not the honor that cometh from God only?" ( c.

[69:11] v.

[69:12] ) So then they were not rulers, but slaves in the utmost slavery.

[69:13] However, this fear was afterwards done away, for nowhere during the time of the Apostles do we find them possessed by this feeling, since in their time both rulers and priests believed.

[69:14] The grace of the Spirit having come, made them all firmer than adamant.

[69:15] Since therefore this was what hindered them from believing at this time, hear what He saith.

[69:16] Ver.

[69:17] "He that believeth on Me, believeth not on Me, but on Him that sent Me".

[69:18] As though He had said, "Why fear ye to believe on Me? Faith passeth to the Father through Me, as doth also unbelief".

[69:19] See how in every way He showeth the unvaryingness of His Essence.

[69:20] He said not, He that believeth "Me," lest any should assert that He spake concerning His words; this might have been said in the case of mere men, for he that believeth the Apostles, believeth not them, but God.

[69:21] But that thou mightest learn that He speaketh here of the belief on His Essence, He said not, "He that believeth My words," but, "He that believeth on Me".

[69:22] "And wherefore," saith some one, "hath He nowhere said conversely, He that believeth on the Father, believeth not on the Father but on Me?" Because they would have replied, "Lo, we believe on the Father, but we believe not on thee".

[69:23] Their disposition was as yet too infirm.

[69:24] Anyhow, conversing with the disciples, He did speak thus: "Ye believe on the Father, believe also on Me" ( c.

[69:25] xiv.

[69:26] ); but seeing that these then were too weak to hear such words, He leadeth them in another way, showing that it is not possible to believe on the Father, without believing on Him.

[69:27] And that thou mayest not deem that the words are spoken as of man, He addeth,  Ver.

[69:28] "He that seeth Me, seeth Him that sent Me".

[69:29] What then! Is God a body? By no means.

[69:30] The "seeing" of which He here speaketh is that of the mind, thence showing the Consubstantiality.

[69:31] And what is, "He that believeth on Me"? It is as though one should say, "He that taketh water from the river, taketh it not from the river but from the fountain"; or rather this image is too weak, when compared with the matter before us.

[69:32] Ver.

[69:33] "I am come a light into the world".

[69:34] For since the Father is called by this name everywhere both in the Old (Testament) and in the New, Christ useth the same name also; therefore Paul also calleth Him, "Brightness" ( Heb.

[69:35] i.

[69:36] ), having learnt to do so from this source.

[69:37] And He showeth here His close relationship with the Father, and that there is no separation between them, if so be that He saith that faith on Him is not on Him, but passeth on to the Father.

[69:38] And He called Himself "light," because He delivereth from error, and dissolveth mental darkness.

[69:39] Ver.

[69:40] "If any man hear not Me, and believe not, I judge him not, for I came not to judge the world, but to save the world".

[69:41] For lest they should think, that for want of power He passed by the despisers, therefore spake He the, "I came not to judge the world".

[69:42] Then, in order that they might not in this way be made more negligent, when they had learned that "he that believeth is saved, and he that disbelieveth is punished," see how He hath also set before them a fearful court of judgment, by going on to say,  Ver.

[69:43] "He that rejecteth Me, and receiveth not My words, hath One to judge him".

[69:44] "If the Father judgeth no man, and thou art not come to judge the world, who judgeth him?" "The word that I have spoken, the same shall judge him".

[69:45] For since they said, "He is not from God," He saith this, that, "they shall not then be able to say these things, but the words which I have spoken now, shall be in place of an accuser, convicting them, and cutting off all excuse".

[69:46] "And the word which I have spoken".

[69:47] What manner of word?  Ver.

[69:48] "For I have not spoken of Myself, but the Father which sent Me, He gave Me a commandment what I should say, and what I should speak".

[69:49] And other such like.

[69:50] Surely these things were said for their sakes, that they might have no pretense of excuse.

[69:51] Since if this were not the case, what shall He have more than Isaiah? for he too saith the very same thing, "The Lord God giveth me the tongue of the learned, that I should know when I ought to speak a word".

[69:52] ( Isa.

[69:53] l.

[69:54] , LXX.

[69:55] ) What more than Jeremiah? for he too when he was sent was inspired.

[69:56] ( Jer.

[69:57] i.

[69:58] ) What then Ezekiel? for he too, after eating the roll, so spake.

[69:59] ( Ezek.

[69:60] iii.

[69:61] ) Otherwise also, they who were about to hear what He said shall be found to be causes of His knowledge.

[69:62] For if when He was sent, He then received commandment what He should say, thou wilt then argue that before He was sent He knew not.

[69:63] And what more impious than these assertions? if (that is) one take the words of Christ in this sense, and understand not the cause of their lowliness? Yet Paul saith, that both he and those who were made disciples knew "what was that good and acceptable and perfect will of God" ( Rom.

[69:64] xii.

[69:65] ), and did the Son not know until He had received commandment? How can this be reasonable? Seest thou not that He bringeth His expressions to an excess of humility, that He may both draw those men over, and silence those who should come after.

[69:66] This is why He uttereth words befitting a mere man, that even so He may force us to fly the meanness of the sayings, as being conscious that the words belong not to His Nature, but are suited to the infirmity of the hearers.

[69:67] Ver.

[69:68] "And I know that His commandment is life everlasting; whatsoever I speak therefore, even as the Father said unto Me, so I speak".

[69:69] Seest thou the humility of the words? For he that hath received a commandment is not his own master.

[69:70] Yet He saith, "As the Father raiseth up the dead and quickeneth them, even so the Son quickeneth whom He will".

[69:71] ( c.

[69:72] v.

[69:73] ) Hath He then power to quicken whom He will, and to say what He will hath He not power? What He intendeth then by the words is this; "The action hath not natural possibility, that He should speak one set of words, and I should utter another".

[69:74] "And I know that His commandment is life everlasting".

[69:75] He said this to those that called Him a deceiver, and asserted that He had come to do hurt.

[69:76] But when He saith, "I judge not," He showeth that He is not the cause of the perdition of these men.

[69:77] By this He all but plainly testifies, when about to remove from, and to be no more with, them, that "I converse with you, speaking nothing as of Myself, but all as from the Father".

[69:78] And for this cause He confined His discourse to them to humble expressions, that He might say, "Even until the end did I utter this, My last word, to them".

[69:79] What word was that? "As the Father said unto Me, so I speak".

[69:80] "Had I been opposed to God I should have said the contrary, that I speak nothing of what is pleasing to God, so as to attract the honor to Myself, but now I have so referred all things to Him, as to call nothing My own.

[69:81] Why then do ye not believe Me when I say that 'I have received a commandment,' and when I so vehemently remove your evil suspicion respecting rivalry? For as it is impossible for those who have received a commandment to do or say anything but what their senders wish, as long as they fulfill the commandment, and do not forge anything; so neither is it possible for Me to say or do anything except as My Father willeth.

[69:82] For what I do He doeth, because He is with Me, and 'the Father hath not left Me alone.

[69:83] '" ( c.

[69:84] viii.

[69:85] ) Seest thou how everywhere He showeth Himself connected with Him who begat Him, and that there is no separation? For when He saith, "I am not come of Myself," He saith it not, as depriving Himself of power, but as taking away all alienation or opposition.

[69:86] For if men are masters of themselves, much more the Only-begotten Son.

[69:87] And to show that this is true, hear what Paul saith, "He emptied Himself, and gave Himself for us".

[69:88] ( Philip.

[69:89] ii.

[69:90] ) But, as I said, a terrible thing is vainglory, very terrible ( Eph.

[69:91] v.

[69:92] ); for this made these men not to believe, and others to believe ill, so that the things which were said for the sake of those men, through lovingkindness, they turned to impiety.

[69:93] Let us then ever flee this monster: various and manifold it is, and everywhere sheds its peculiar venom, in wealth, in luxury, in beauty of person.

[69:94] Through this we everywhere go beyond needful use; through this arises extravagance in garments, and a great swarm of domestics; through this the needful use is every where despised, in our houses, our garments, our table; and extravagance prevails.

[69:95] Wilt thou enjoy glory? Do alms-deeds, then shall Angels praise thee, then shall God receive thee.

[69:96] Now the admiration goes no farther than the goldsmiths and weavers, and thou departest without a crown, often seeing that thou receivest curses.

[69:97] But if thou put not these things about thy body, but expend them in feeding the poor, great will be the applause from all sides, great the praise.

[69:98] Then shalt thou have them, when thou givest them to others; when thou keepest them to thyself, then thou hast them not.

[69:99] For a house is a faithless treasury, but a sure treasury are the hands of the poor.

[69:100] Why adornest thou thy body, while thy soul is neglected, possessed by uncleanness? Why bestowest thou not so much thought on thy soul, as thy body? Thou oughtest to bestow greater; but anyhow, beloved, we ought to bestow equal care upon it.

[69:101] For tell me, if any one asked thee which thou wouldest choose, that thy body should be fresh and of good habit and surpassing in beauty, and wear mean raiment, or having the body deformed and full of diseases, to wear gold and finery; wouldest thou not much prefer to have beauty depending on the nature of thy person, than on the raiment with which thou art clothed? And wilt thou choose this in the case of thy body, but the contrary in the case of thy soul; and, when thou hast that ugly and unsightly and black, dost thou think to gain anything from golden ornaments? What madness is this! Shift this adorning within, put these necklaces about thy soul.

[69:102] The things that are put about thy body help neither to its health nor to its beauty, for it will not make black white, nor what is ugly either beautiful or good looking.

[69:103] But if thou put them about thy soul, thou shalt soon make it white instead of black, instead of ugly and unsightly, thou shalt make it beautiful and well-favored.

[69:104] The words are not mine, but those of the Lord Himself, who saith, "Though thy sins be as scarlet, I will make them white as snow" ( Isa.

[69:105] i.

[69:106] , LXX.

[69:107] ); and, "Give alms—and all things shall be clean unto you" ( Luke xi.

[69:108] ); and by such a disposition thou shalt beautify not thyself only, but thy husband.

[69:109] For they if they see you putting off these outward ornaments, will have no great need of expense, and not having it, they will abstain from all covetousness, and will be more inclined to give alms, and ye too will be able boldly to give them fitting counsel.

[69:110] At present ye are deprived of all such authority.

[69:111] For with what mouth will ye speak of these things? with what eyes will ye look your husbands in the face, asking money for alms, when ye spend most upon the covering of your bodies? Then wilt thou be able boldly to speak with thy husband concerning alms-giving, when thou layest aside thine ornaments of gold.

[69:112] Even if thou accomplish nothing, thou hast fulfilled all thy part; but I should rather say, that it is impossible that the wife should not gain the husband, when she speaks by the very actions.

[69:113] "For what knowest thou, O woman, whether thou shalt save thy husband?" (  Cor.

[69:114] vii.

[69:115] ) As then now thou shalt give account both for thyself and for him, so if thou put off all this vanity thou shalt have a double crown, wearing thy crown and triumphing with thy husband through those unalloyed ages, and enjoying the everlasting good things, which may we all obtain, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, to whom be glory for ever and ever, Amen.

[70:1] Homily LXX.

[70:2] John xiii.

[70:3] "Now before the feast of the Passover, when Jesus knew that His hour was come that He should depart out of this world unto the Father, having loved His own which were in the world, He loved them unto the end".

[70:4] "Be ye imitators of me," said Paul, "as I also am of Christ".

[70:5] (  Cor.

[70:6] xi.

[70:7] ) For on this account He took also flesh of our substance, that by means of it He might teach us virtue.

[70:8] For ("God sending His own Son) in the likeness of sinful flesh," it saith, "and for sin condemned sin in the flesh".

[70:9] ( Rom.

[70:10] viii.

[70:11] ) And Christ Himself saith, "Learn of Me, for I am meek and lowly in heart".

[70:12] ( Matt.

[70:13] xi.

[70:14] ) And this He taught, not by words alone, but by actions also.

[70:15] For they called Him a Samaritan, and one that had a devil, and a deceiver, and cast stones at Him; and at one time the Pharisees sent servants to take Him, at another they sent plotters against Him; and they continued also insulting Him themselves, and that when they had no fault to find, but were even being continually benefited.

[70:16] Still after such conduct He ceaseth not to do well to them both by words and deeds.

[70:17] And, when a certain domestic smote Him on the face, He said, "If I have spoken evil, bear witness of the evil, but if well, why smitest thou Me?" ( c.

[70:18] xviii.

[70:19] ) But this was to those who hated and plotted against Him.

[70:20] Let us see also what He doeth now towards the disciples, or rather what actions He now exhibiteth towards the traitor.

[70:21] The man whom most of all there was reason to hate, because being a disciple, having shared the table and the salt, having seen the miracles and been deemed worthy of such great things, he acted more grievously than any, not stoning indeed, nor insulting Him, but betraying and giving Him up, observe in how friendly sort He receiveth this man, washing his feet; for even in this way He desired to restrain him from that wickedness.

[70:22] Yet it was in His power, had He willed it, to have withered him like the fig-tree, to have cut him in two as He rent the rocks, to have cleft him asunder like the veil; but He would not lead him away from his design by compulsion, but by choice.

[70:23] Wherefore He washed his feet; and not even by this was that wretched and miserable man shamed.

[70:24] "Before the feast of the Passover," it saith, "Jesus knowing that His hour was come".

[70:25] Not then "knowing," but (it means) that He did what He did having "known" long ago.

[70:26] "That He should depart".

[70:27] Magnificently the Evangelist calleth His death, "departure".

[70:28] "Having loved His own, He loved them unto the end".

[70:29] Seest thou how when about to leave them He showeth greater love? For the, "having loved, He loved them unto the end," showeth that he omitted nothing of the things which it was likely that one who earnestly loved would do.

[70:30] Why, then did He not this from the beginning? He worketh the greatest things last, so as to render more intense their attachment, and to lay up for them beforehand much comfort, against the terrible things that were about to fall on them.

[70:31] St.

[70:32] John calls them "His own," in respect of personal attachment, since he calls others also "His own," in respect of the work of creation; as when he saith, "His own received Him not".

[70:33] ( c.

[70:34] i.

[70:35] ) But what meaneth, "which were in the world"? Because the dead also were "His own," Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and the men of that sort, but they were not in the world.

[70:36] Seest thou that He is the God both of the Old and New (Testament)? But what meaneth, "He loved them unto the end"? It stands for, "He continued loving them unceasingly," and this the Evangelist mentions as a sure proof of great affection.

[70:37] Elsewhere indeed He spake of another (proof), the laying down life for His friends; but that had not yet come to pass.

[70:38] And wherefore did He this thing "now"? Because it was far more wonderful at a time when He appeared more glorious in the sight of all men.

[70:39] Besides, He left them no small consolation now that He was about to depart, for since they were going to be greatly grieved, He by these means introduceth also comfort to the grief.

[70:40] Ver.

[70:41] "And supper being ended, the devil having now put it into the heart of Judas to betray Him".

[70:42] This the Evangelist hath said amazed, showing that Jesus washed the man who had already chosen to betray Him.

[70:43] This also proves his great wickedness, that not even the having shared the salt restrained him, (a thing which is most able to restrain wickedness;) not the fact that even up to the last day, his Master continued to bear with him.

[70:44] Ver.

[70:45] "Jesus knowing that the Father had given all things into His hands, and that He was come from God, and went to God".

[70:46] Here the Evangelist saith, even wondering, that one so great, so very great, who came from God and went to Him, who ruleth over all, did this thing, and disdained not even so to undertake such an action.

[70:47] And by the "giving over," methinks St.

[70:48] John means the salvation of the faithful.

[70:49] For when He saith, "All things are given over to Me of My Father" ( Matt.

[70:50] xi.

[70:51] ), He speaketh of this kind of giving over; as also in another place He saith, "Thine they were, and Thou gavest them Me" ( c.

[70:52] xvii.

[70:53] ); and again, "No man can come unto Me except the Father draw him" ( c.

[70:54] vi.

[70:55] ); and, "Except it be given him from heaven".

[70:56] ( c.

[70:57] iii.

[70:58] ) The Evangelist then either means this, or that Christ would be nothing lessened by this action, since He came from God, and went to God, and possessed all things.

[70:59] But when thou hearest of "giving over," understand it in no human sense, for it showeth how He honoreth the Father, and His unanimity with Him.

[70:60] For as the Father giveth over to Him, so He to the Father.

[70:61] And this Paul declares, saying, "When He shall have given over the kingdom to God, even the Father".

[70:62] (  Cor.

[70:63] xv.

[70:64] ) But St.

[70:65] John hath said it here in a more human sense, showing His great care for them, and declaring His unutterable love, that He now cared for them as for His own; teaching them the mother of all good, even humblemindedness, which He said was both the beginning and the end of virtue.

[70:66] And not without a reason is added the, "He came from God and went to God": but that we may learn that He did what was worthy of One who came thence and went thither, trampling down all pride.

[70:67] Ver.

[70:68] "And having risen from supper, and laid aside His garments".

[70:69] Observe how not by the washing only, but in another way also He exhibiteth humility.

[70:70] For it was not before reclining, but after they had all sat down, then He arose.

[70:71] In the next place, He doth not merely wash them, but doth so, putting off His garments.

[70:72] And He did not even stop here, but girded Himself with a towel.

[70:73] Nor was He satisfied with this, but Himself filled (the basin), and did not bid another fill it; He did all these things Himself, showing by all that we must do such things, when we are engaged in well doing, not merely for form's sake, but with all zeal.

[70:74] Now He seemeth to me to have washed the feet of the traitor first from its saying,  Ver.

[70:75] "He began to wash the disciples' feet," and adding,  Ver.

[70:76] "Then cometh He to Simon Peter and Peter saith unto Him, Lord, dost Thou wash my feet?"  "With those hands," he saith, "with which Thou hast opened eyes, and cleansed lepers, and raised the dead?" For this (question) is very emphatic; wherefore He needed not to have said any more than the, "Thou"; for even of itself this would have sufficed to convey the whole.

[70:77] Some one might reasonably enquire, how none of the others forbade Him, but Peter only, which was a mark of no slight love and reverence.

[70:78] What then is the cause? He seemeth to me to have washed the traitor first, then to have come to Peter, and that the others were afterwards instructed from his case.

[70:79] That He washed some one other before him is clear from its saying, "But when He came to Peter".

[70:80] Yet the Evangelist is not a vehement accuser, for the "began," is the expression of one implying this.

[70:81] And even if Peter were the first, yet it is probable that the traitor, being a forward person, had reclined even before the chief.

[70:82] For by another circumstance also his forwardness is shown, when He dippeth with his Master in the dish, and being convicted, feels no compunction; while Peter being rebuked but once on a former occasion, and for words which he spake from loving affection, was so abashed, that being even distressed and trembling, he begged another to ask a question.

[70:83] But Judas, though continually convicted, felt not.

[70:84] ( Ver.

[70:85] ) When therefore He came to Peter, he saith unto Him, "Lord, dost Thou wash my feet?"  Ver.

[70:86] "He saith unto him, What I do thou knowest not now, but thou shalt know here after".

[70:87] That is "thou shalt know how great is the gain from this, the profit of the lesson, and how it is able to guide us into all humblemindedness".

[70:88] What then doth Peter? He still hinders Him, and saith,  Ver.

[70:89] "Thou shalt never wash my feet".

[70:90] "What doest thou, Peter? Rememberest thou not those former words? Saidst thou not, 'Be merciful to Thyself,' and heardest thou not in return, 'Get thee behind Me, Satan'? ( Matt.

[70:91] xvi.

[70:92] ) Art thou not even so sobered, but art thou yet vehement?" "Yea," he saith, "for what is being done is a great matter, and full of amazement".

[70:93] Since then he did this from exceeding love, Christ in turn subdueth him by the same; and as there He effected this by sharply rebuking him, and saying, "Thou art an offense unto Me," so here also by saying,  "If I wash thee not, thou hast no part with Me".

[70:94] What then saith that hot and burning one?  Ver.

[70:95] "Lord, not my feet only, but also my hands and my head".

[70:96] Vehement in deprecation, he becometh yet more vehement in acquiescence; but both from love.

[70:97] For why said He not wherefore He did this, instead of adding a threat? Because Peter would not have been persuaded.

[70:98] For had He said, "Suffer it, for by this I persuade you to be humbleminded," Peter would have promised it ten thousand times, in order that his Master might not do this thing.

[70:99] But now what saith He? He speaketh of that which Peter most feared and dreaded, the being separated from Him; for it is he who continually asks, "Whither goest Thou?" ( Ver.

[70:100] ) Wherefore also he said, "I will give even my life for Thee".

[70:101] ( Ver.

[70:102] ) And if, after hearing, "What I do thou knowest not now, but thou shalt know hereafter," he still persisted, much more would he have done so had he learnt (the meaning of the action).

[70:103] Therefore said He, "but thou shalt know hereafter," as being aware, that should he learn it immediately he would still resist.

[70:104] And Peter said not, "Tell me, that I may suffer Thee," but (which was much more vehement) he did not even endure to learn, but withstands Him, saying, "Thou shalt never wash my feet".

[70:105] But as soon as He threatened, he straightway relaxed his tone.

[70:106] But what meaneth, "Thou shalt know after this"? "After this?" When? "When in My Name thou shalt have cast out devils; when thou shalt have seen Me taken up into Heaven, when thou shalt have learnt from the Spirit that I sit on His right hand, then shalt thou understand what is being done now".

[70:107] What then saith Christ? When Peter said, "not my feet only, but also my hands and my head," He replieth,  Ver.

[70:108] ,.

[70:109] "He that is washed, needeth not save to wash his feet, but is clean every whit; and ye are clean, but not all.

[70:110] For He knew who should betray Him".

[70:111] "And if they are clean, why washeth He their feet?" That we may learn to be modest.

[70:112] On which account He came not to any other part of the body, but to that which is considered more dishonorable than the rest.

[70:113] But what is, "He that is washed"? It is instead of, "he that is clean".

[70:114] Were they then clean, who had not yet been delivered from their sins, nor deemed worthy of the Spirit, since sin still had the mastery, the handwriting of the curse still remaining, the victim not having yet been offered? How then calleth He them "clean"? That thou mayest not deem them clean, as delivered from their sins, He addeth, Behold, "ye are clean through the word that I have spoken unto you".

[70:115] That is, "In this way ye are so far clean; ye have received the light, ye have been freed from Jewish error.

[70:116] For the Prophet also saith, 'Wash you, make you clean, put away the wickedness from your souls' ( Isa.

[70:117] i.

[70:118] , LXX.

[70:119] ); so that such a one is washed and is clean".

[70:120] Since then these men had cast away all wickedness from their souls, and had companied with Him with a pure mind, therefore He saith according to the word of the Prophet, "he that is washed is clean already".

[70:121] For in that place also It meaneth not the "washing" of water, practiced by the Jews; but the cleansing of the conscience.

[70:122] Be we then also clean; learn we to do well.

[70:123] But what is "well"? "Judge for the fatherless, plead for the widow; and come, let us reason together, saith the Lord".

[70:124] ( Isa.

[70:125] i.

[70:126] ) There is frequent mention in the Scriptures of widows and orphans, but we make no account of this.

[70:127] Yet consider how great is the reward.

[70:128] "Though," it saith, "your sins be as scarlet, I will whiten them as snow; though they be red like crimson, I will whiten them as wool".

[70:129] For a widow is an unprotected being, therefore He taketh much care for her.

[70:130] For they, when it is even in their power to contract a second marriage, endure the hardships of widowhood through fear of God.

[70:131] Let us then all, both men and women, stretch forth our hands to them, that we may never undergo the sorrows of widow-hood; or if we should have to undergo them, let us lay up a great store of kindness for ourselves.

[70:132] Not small is the power of the widow's tears, it is able to open heaven itself.

[70:133] Let us not then trample on them, nor make their calamity worse, but assist them by every means.

[70:134] If so we do, we shall put around ourselves much safety, both in the present life, and in that which is to come.

[70:135] For not here alone, but there also will they be our defenders, cutting away most of our sins by reason of our beneficence towards them, and causing us to stand boldly before the judgment-seat of Christ.

[70:136] Which may it come to pass that we all obtain, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, to whom be glory for ever and ever, Amen.

[71:1] Homily LXXI.

[71:2] John xiii  "And He took His garments, and having sat down again, said unto them, Know ye what I have done to you?" And what follows.

[71:3] A grievous thing, beloved, a grievous thing it is to come to the depths of wickedness; for then the soul becomes hard to be restored.

[71:4] Wherefore we should use every exertion not to be taken at all; since it is easier not to fall in, than having fallen to recover one's self.

[71:5] Observe, for instance, when Judas had thrown himself into sin, how great assistance he enjoyed, yet not even so was he raised.

[71:6] Christ said to him, "One of you is a devil" ( c.

[71:7] vi.

[71:8] ); He said, "Not all believe" ( c.

[71:9] vi.

[71:10] ); He said, "I speak not of all," and, "I know whom I have chosen" ( c.

[71:11] xiii.

[71:12] ); and not one of these sayings doth he feel.

[71:13] Now when He had washed their feet, and taken His garments, and sat down, He said, "Know ye what I have done unto you?" He no longer addresseth Himself to Peter only, but to them all.

[71:14] Ver.

[71:15] "Ye call Me Lord and Master, and ye say well, for so I am".

[71:16] "Ye call Me".

[71:17] He taketh to Him their judgment, and then that the words may not be thought to be words of their kindness, He addeth, "for so I am".

[71:18] By introducing a saying of theirs, He maketh it not offensive, and by confirming it Himself when introduced from them, unsuspected.

[71:19] "For so I am," He saith.

[71:20] Seest thou how when He converseth with the disciples, He speaketh revealing more what belongeth unto Himself? As He saith, "Call no man master on earth, for One is your guide" ( Matt.

[71:21] xxiii.

[71:22] ,  ), so also, "And call no man father upon earth".

[71:23] But the "one" and "one" is spoken not of the Father only, but of Himself also.

[71:24] For had He spoken excluding Himself, how saith He, "That ye may become the children of the light"? And again, if He called the Father only, "Master," how saith He, "For so I am"; and again, "For one is your Guide, even Christ"? ( c.

[71:25] xii.

[71:26] )  Ver.

[71:27] ,.

[71:28] "If I then," He saith, "your Lord and Master have washed your feet, ye ought also to wash one another's feet.

[71:29] For I have given you an example, that ye should do as I have done to you".

[71:30] And yet it is not the same thing, for He is Lord and Master, but ye are fellow-servants one of another.

[71:31] What meaneth then the "as"? "With the same zeal".

[71:32] For on this account He taketh instances from greater actions that we may, if so be, perform the less.

[71:33] Thus schoolmasters write the letters for children very beautifully, that they may come to imitate them though but in an inferior manner.

[71:34] Where now are they who spit on their fellow-servants? where now they who demand honors? Christ washed the feet of the traitor, the sacrilegious, the thief, and that close to the time of the betrayal, and incurable as he was, made him a partaker of His table; and art thou highminded, and dost thou draw up thine eyebrows? "Let us then wash one another's feet," saith some one, "then we must wash those of our domestics".

[71:35] And what great thing if we do wash even those of our domestics? In our case "slave" and "free" is a difference of words; but there an actual reality.

[71:36] For by nature He was Lord and we servants, yet even this He refused not at this time to do.

[71:37] But now it is matter for contentment if we do not treat free men as bondmen, as slaves bought with money.

[71:38] And what shall we say in that day, if after receiving proofs of such forbearance, we ourselves do not imitate them at all, but take the contrary part, being in diametrical opposition, lifted up, and not discharging the debt? For God hath made us debtors one to another, having first so done Himself, and hath made us debtors of a less amount.

[71:39] For He was our Lord, but we do it, if we do it at all, to our fellow-servants, a thing which He Himself implied by saying, "If I then your Lord and Master—so also do ye".

[71:40] It would indeed naturally have followed to say, "How much more should ye servants," but He left this to the conscience of the hearers.

[71:41] But why hath He done this "now"? They were for the future to enjoy, some greater, some less honor.

[71:42] In order then that they may not exalt themselves one above the other, and say as they did before, "Who is the greatest" ( Matt.

[71:43] xviii.

[71:44] ), nor be angry one against the other, He taketh down the high thoughts of them all, by saying, that "although thou mayest be very great, thou oughtest to have no high thoughts towards thy brother".

[71:45] And He mentioned not the greater action, that "if I have washed the feet of the traitor, what great matter if ye one another's?" but having exemplified this by deeds, He then left it to the judgment of the spectators.

[71:46] Therefore He said, "Whosoever shall do and teach, the same shall be called great" ( Matt.

[71:47] v.

[71:48] ); for this is "to teach" a thing, actually to do it.

[71:49] What pride should not this remove? what kind of folly and insolence should it not annihilate! He who sitteth upon the Cherubim washed the feet of the traitor, and dost thou, O man, thou that art earth and ashes and cinders and dust, dost thou exalt thyself, and art thou highminded? And how great a hell wouldest thou not deserve? If then thou desirest a high state of mind, come, I will show thee the way to it; for thou dost not even know what it is.

[71:50] The man then who gives heed to the present things as being great, is of a mean soul; so that there can neither be humility without greatness of soul, nor conceit except from littleness of soul.

[71:51] For as little children are eager for trifles, gaping upon balls and hoops and dice, but cannot even form an idea of important matters; so in this case, one who is truly wise, will deem present things as nothing, (so that he will neither choose to acquire them himself, nor to receive them from others;) but he who is not of such a character will be affected in a contrary way, intent upon cobwebs and shadows and dreams of things less substantial than these.

[71:52] Ver.

[71:53] –.

[71:54] "Verily I say unto you, the servant is not greater than his lord, neither he that is sent greater than he that sent him.

[71:55] If ye know these things, happy are ye if ye do them.

[71:56] I speak not of you all —but that the Scripture may be fulfilled, He that eateth bread with Me hath lifted up his heel against Me".

[71:57] What He said before, this He saith here also, to shame them; "For if the servant is not greater than his master, nor he that is sent greater than him that sent him, and these things have been done by Me, much more ought they to be done by you".

[71:58] Then, lest any one should say, "Why now sayest Thou these things? Do we not already know them?" He addeth this very thing, "I speak not to you as not knowing, but that by your actions ye may show forth the things spoken of".

[71:59] For "to know," belongeth to all; but "to do," not to all.

[71:60] On this account He said, "Blessed are ye if ye do them"; and on this account I continually and ever say the same to you, although ye know it, that I may set you on the work.

[71:61] Since even Jews "know," but yet they are not "blessed"; for they do not what they know.

[71:62] "I speak not," He saith, "of you all".

[71:63] O what forbearance! Not yet doth He convict the traitor, but veileth the matter, hence giving him room for repentance.

[71:64] He convicteth and yet doth not convict him when He saith thus, "He that eateth bread with Me hath lifted up his heel against Me".

[71:65] It seems to me that the, "The servant is not greater than his lord," was uttered for this purpose also, that if any persons should at any time suffer harm either from domestics or from any of the meaner sort, they should not be offended; looking to the instance of Judas, who having enjoyed ten thousand good things, repaid his Benefactor with the contrary.

[71:66] On this account He added, "He that eateth bread with Me," and letting pass all the rest, He hath put that which was most fitted to restrain and shame him; "he who was fed by Me," He saith, "and who shared My table".

[71:67] And He spake the words, to instruct them to benefit those who did evil to them, even though such persons should continue incurable.

[71:68] But having said, "I speak not of you all," in order not to attach fear to more than one, He at last separateth the traitor, speaking thus; "He that eateth bread with Me".

[71:69] For the, "not of you all," doth not direct the words to any single one, therefore He added, "He that eateth bread with Me"; showing to that wretched one that He was not seized in ignorance, but even with full knowledge; a thing which of itself was most of all fitted to restrain him.

[71:70] And He said not, "betrayeth Me," but, "hath lifted up his heel against Me," desiring to represent the deceit, the treachery, the secrecy of the plot.

[71:71] These things are written that we bear not malice towards those who injure us; but rebuke them and weep for them; for the fit subjects of weeping are not they who suffer, but they who do the wrong.

[71:72] The grasping man, the false accuser, and whoso worketh any other evil thing, do themselves the greatest injury, and us the greatest good, if we do not avenge ourselves.

[71:73] Such a case as this: some one has robbed thee; hast thou given thanks for the injury, and glorified God? by that thanksgiving thou hast gained ten thousand rewards, just as he hath gathered for himself fire unspeakable.

[71:74] But if any one say, "How then, if I 'could' not defend myself against him who wronged me, being weaker?" I would say this, that thou couldest have put into action the being discontented, the being impatient, (for these things are in our power,) the praying against him, who grieved you, the uttering ten thousand curses against him, the speaking ill of him to every one.

[71:75] He therefore who hath not done these things shall even be rewarded for not defending himself, since it is clear that even if he had had the power, he would not have done it.

[71:76] The injured man uses any weapon that comes to hand, when, being little of soul, he defends himself against one who has injured him, by curses, by abuse, by plotting.

[71:77] Do thou then not only not do these things, but even pray for him; for if thou do them not, but wilt even pray for him, thou art become like unto God.

[71:78] For, "pray," it saith, "for them, that despitefully use you—that ye may be like unto your Father which is in Heaven".

[71:79] ( Matt.

[71:80] v.

[71:81] ,.

[71:82] ) Seest thou how we are the greatest gainers from the insolence of others? Nothing so delighteth God, as the not returning evil for evil? But what say I? Not returning evil for evil? Surely we are enjoined to return the opposite, benefits, prayers.

[71:83] Wherefore Christ also repaid him who was about to betray Him with everything opposite.

[71:84] He washed his feet, convicted him secretly, rebuked him sparingly, tended him, allowed him to share His table and His kiss, and not even by these was he made better; nevertheless (Christ) continued doing His own part.

[71:85] But come, let us teach thee even from the example of servants, and (to make the lesson stronger) those in the Old (Testament), that thou mayest know that we have no ground of defense when we remember a wrong.

[71:86] Will you then that I tell you of Moses, or shall we go yet farther back? For the more ancient the instances that can be pointed out, the more are we surpassed.

[71:87] "Why so?" Because virtue was then more difficult.

[71:88] Those men had no written precepts, no patterns of living, but their nature fought, unarmed, by itself, and was forced to float in all directions unballasted.

[71:89] Wherefore also when praising Noah, God called him not simply perfect, but added, "in his generation" ( Gen.

[71:90] vii.

[71:91] ); signifying, "at that time," when there were many hindrances, since many others shone after him, yet will he have nothing less than they; for in his own time he was perfect.

[71:92] Who then before Moses was patient? The blessed and noble Joseph, who having shone by his chastity, shone no less by his long suffering.

[71:93] He was sold when he had done no wrong, but was waiting on others, and serving, and performing all the duties of domestics.

[71:94] They brought against him an evil accusation, and he did not defend himself, though he had his father on his side.

[71:95] Nay, he even went to carry food to them in the desert, and when he found them not, he did not despair or turn back, (yet he had an excuse for doing so had he chosen,) but remained near the wild beasts and those savage men, preserving the feeling of a true brother.

[71:96] Again, when he dwelt in the prison house, and was asked the cause, he spake no evil of them, but only, "I have done nothing," and, "I was stolen out of the land of the Hebrews"; and after this again, when he was made lord, he nourished them, and delivered them from ten thousand dangers.

[71:97] If we be sober, the wickedness of our neighbor is not strong enough to cast us out of our own virtue.

[71:98] But those others were not like him; they both stripped him, and endeavored to kill him, and reproach him with his dream, though they had even received their meat from him, and planned to deprive him of life and of liberty.

[71:99] And they ate, and cared not for their brother lying naked in the pit.

[71:100] What could be worse than such brutality? Were they not worse than any number of murderers? And after this, having drawn him up, they gave him over to ten thousand deaths, selling him to barbarian and savage men, who were on their journey to barbarians.

[71:101] Yet he, when he became ruler, not only remitted them their punishment, but even acquitted them, as far at least as relating to himself, of their sin, calling what had been done a dispensation of God, not any wickedness of theirs; and the things which he did against them he did not as remembering evil, but in all these he dissembled, for his brother's sake.

[71:102] After this, when he saw them clinging to him, he straightway threw away the mask, and wept aloud, and embraced them, as though he had received the greatest benefits, he, who formerly was made away with by them, and he brought them all down into Egypt, and repaid them with ten thousand benefits.

[71:103] What excuse then shall we have, if after the Law, and after grace, and after the addition of so much heavenly wisdom, we do not even strive to rival him who lived before grace and before the Law? Who shall deliver us from punishment? For there is nothing, there is nothing more grievous than the remembrance of injuries.

[71:104] And this the man hath showed that owed ten thousand talents; from whom payment was at one time not demanded, at another time again demanded; not demanded, because of the lovingkindness of God; but demanded, because of his own wickedness, and because of his malice toward his fellow-servant.

[71:105] Knowing all which things, let us forgive our neighbors their trespasses, and repay them by deeds of an opposite kind, that we too may obtain mercy from God, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, to whom be glory and dominion for ever and ever, Amen.

[72:1] Homily LXXII.

[72:2] John xiii.

[72:3] "Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that receiveth whomsoever I send, receiveth Me: and He that receiveth Me, receiveth Him that sent Me".

[72:4] Great is the recompense of care bestowed upon the servants of God, and of itself it yieldeth to us its fruits.

[72:5] For, "he that receiveth you," it saith, "receiveth Me, and he that receiveth Me, receiveth Him that sent Me".

[72:6] ( Matt.

[72:7] x.

[72:8] ) Now what can be equal to the receiving Christ and His Father? But what kind of connection hath this with what was said before? What hath it in common with that which He had said, "If ye do these things happy are ye," to add, "He that receiveth you"? A close connection, and very harmonious.

[72:9] Observe how.

[72:10] When they were about to go forth and to suffer many dreadful things, He comforteth them in two ways; one derived from Himself, the other derived from others.

[72:11] "For if," He saith, "ye are truly wise, ever keeping Me in mind, and bearing about all both what I said, and what I did, ye will easily endure terrible things.

[72:12] And not in this way only, but also from your enjoying great attention from all men".

[72:13] The first point He declared when He said, "If ye do these things happy are ye"; the second when He said, "He that receiveth you receiveth Me".

[72:14] For He opened the houses of all men to them, so that both from the sound wisdom of their manners, and the zeal of those who would tend them, they might have twofold comfort.

[72:15] Then when He had given these directions to them as to men about to run through all the world, reflecting that the traitor was deprived of both of these things, and would enjoy neither of them, neither patience in toils, nor the service of kind entertainers, He again was troubled.

[72:16] And the Evangelist to signify this besides, and to show that it was on his account that He was troubled, adds,  Ver.

[72:17] "When Jesus had thus said, He was troubled in spirit, and testified, and said, Verily, verily, I say unto you, that one of you shall betray Me".

[72:18] Again He bringeth fear on all by not mentioning (the traitor) by name.

[72:19] Ver.

[72:20] "But they are in doubt"; although conscious to themselves of nothing evil; but they deemed the declaration of Christ more to be believed than their own thoughts.

[72:21] Wherefore they "looked one on another".

[72:22] By laying the whole upon one, Jesus would have cut short their fear, but by adding, "one of you," He troubled all.

[72:23] What then? The rest looked upon one another; but the ever fervent Peter "beckoneth" to John.

[72:24] Since he had been before rebuked, and when Christ desired to wash him would have hindered Him, and since he is everywhere found moved indeed by love, yet blamed; being on this account afraid, he neither kept quiet, nor did he speak, but wished to gain information by means of John.

[72:25] But it is a question worth asking, why when all were distressed, and trembling, when their leader was afraid, John like one at ease leans on Jesus' bosom, and not only leans, but even (lies) on His breast? Nor is this the only thing worthy of enquiry, but that also which follows.

[72:26] What is that? What he saith of himself, "Whom Jesus loved".

[72:27] Why did no one else say this of himself? yet the others were loved too.

[72:28] But he more than any.

[72:29] And if no other hath said this about him, but he about himself, it is nothing wonderful.

[72:30] Paul too does the same, when occasion calls, saying thus, "I knew a man fourteen years ago"; yet in fact he has gone through other no trifling praises of himself.

[72:31] Seems it to thee a small thing that, when he had heard, "Follow Me," he straightway left his nets, and his father, and followed; and that Christ took him alone with Peter into the mountain, ( Matt.

[72:32] xvii.

[72:33] ,) and another time again when He went into a house? ( Luke viii.

[72:34] ) What high praise also has he himself passed on Peter without concealment, telling us that Christ said, "Peter, lovest thou Me more than these?" ( c.

[72:35] xxi.

[72:36] ), and everywhere he showeth him warm, and nobly disposed towards himself; for instance, when he said, "Lord, and what shall this man do?" he spake from great love.

[72:37] But why did no other say (this) concerning him? Because he would not himself have said it, unless he had come to this passage.

[72:38] For if after telling us that Peter beckoned to John to ask, he had added nothing more, he would have caused considerable doubt, and have compelled us to enquire into the reason.

[72:39] In order therefore himself to solve this difficulty, he saith, "He lay on the bosom of Jesus".

[72:40] Thinkest thou that thou hast learnt a little thing when thou hast heard that "he lay," and that their Master allowed such boldness to them? If thou desirest to know the cause of this, the action was of love; wherefore he saith, "Whom Jesus loved".

[72:41] I suppose also that John doth this for another reason, as wishing to show that he was exempt from the charge and so he speaks openly and is confident.

[72:42] Again, why did he use these words, not at any other point of time, but only when the chief of the Apostles beckoned? That thou mightest not deem that Peter beckoned to him as being greater, he saith that the thing took place because of the great love (which Jesus bare him).

[72:43] But why doth he even lie on His bosom? They had not as yet formed any high surmises concerning Him; besides, in this way He calmed their despondency; for it is probable that at this time their faces were overclouded.

[72:44] If they were troubled in their souls, much more would they be so in their countenances.

[72:45] Soothing them therefore by word and by the question, He makes a way beforehand, and allows him to lean on His breast.

[72:46] Observe too his modesty; he mentions not his own name, but, "whom He loved".

[72:47] As also Paul, when he said, "I knew a man about fourteen years ago".

[72:48] Now for the first time Jesus convicted the traitor, but not even now by name; but how?  Ver.

[72:49] "He it is, to whom I shall give a sop when I have dipped it".

[72:50] Even the manner (of the rebuke) was calculated to put him to shame.

[72:51] He respected not the table, though he shared the bread; be it so; but the receiving the sop from His own hand, whom would not that have won over? yet him it won not.

[72:52] Ver.

[72:53] "Then Satan entered into him".

[72:54] Laughing at him for his shamelessness.

[72:55] As long as he belonged to the band of disciples he dared not spring upon him, but attacked him from without; but when Christ made him manifest and separated him, then he sprang upon him without fear.

[72:56] It was not fitting to keep within one of such a character, and who so long had remained incorrigible.

[72:57] Wherefore He henceforth cast him out, and then that other seized him when cut off, and he leaving them went forth by night.

[72:58] "Jesus saith unto him, Friend, that thou doest, do quickly".

[72:59] Ver.

[72:60] "Now no man at the table knew with what intent He spake this unto him".

[72:61] Wonderful insensibility! How could it be that he was neither softened nor shamed; but rendered yet more shameless, "went out".

[72:62] The "do quickly," is not the expression of one commanding, nor advising, but of one reproaching, and showing him that He desired to correct him, but that since he was incorrigible, He let him go.

[72:63] And this, the Evangelist saith, "no man of those that sat at the table knew".

[72:64] Some one may perhaps find here a considerable difficulty, if, when the disciples had asked, "Who is it?" and He had answered, "He to whom I shall give a sop when I have dipped it," they did not even so understand; unless indeed He spake it secretly, so that no man should hear.

[72:65] For John on this very account, leaning by His breast, asked Him almost close to His ear, so that the traitor might not be made manifest; and Christ answered in like manner, so that not even then did He discover him.

[72:66] And though He spake emphatically, "Friend, that thou doest, do quickly," even so they understood not.

[72:67] But he spake thus to show that the things were true which had been said by Him to the Jews concerning His death.

[72:68] For He had said to them, "I have power to lay down My life, and I have power to take it again": and, "No man taketh it from Me".

[72:69] ( c.

[72:70] x.

[72:71] ) As long then as He would retain it, no man was able (to take it); but when He resigned it, then the action became easy.

[72:72] All this He implied when He said, "That thou doest, do quickly".

[72:73] Yet not even then did He expose him, for perhaps the others might have torn him in pieces, or Peter might have killed him.

[72:74] On this account "no man at the table knew".

[72:75] Not even John? Not even he: for he could not have expected that a disciple would arrive at such a pitch of wickedness.

[72:76] For since they were far from such iniquity themselves, they could not suspect such things concerning others.

[72:77] As before He had told them, "I speak not of you all" ( ver.

[72:78] ), yet did not reveal the person; so here, they thought that it was said concerning some other matter.

[72:79] "It was night," saith the Evangelist, when he went out.

[72:80] "Why tellest thou me the time?" That thou mayest learn his forwardness, that not even the time restrained him from his purpose.

[72:81] Yet not even did this make him quite manifest, for the others were at this time in confusion, occupied by fear and great distress, and they knew not the true reason of what had been said but supposed that He spake thus, in order that Judas might give somewhat to the poor.

[72:82] For He cared greatly for the poor, teaching us also to bestow much diligence on this thing.

[72:83] But they thought this, not without a cause, but "because he had the bag".

[72:84] Yet no one appears to have brought money to Him; that the female disciples nourished Him of their substance, it has said, but this it hath nowhere intimated.

[72:85] ( Luke viii.

[72:86] ) But how did He who bade His disciples bear neither scrip, nor money, nor staff, Himself bear a bag to minister to the poor? That thou mayest learn, that it behooveth even him who is exceedingly needy and crucified, to be very careful on this point.

[72:87] For many things He did in the way of dispensation for our instruction.

[72:88] The disciples then thought that He said this, that Judas should give something to the poor; and not even this shamed him, His not being willing even to the last day to make him a public example.

[72:89] We too ought to do the like, and not parade the sins of our companions, though they be incurable.

[72:90] For even after this He gave a kiss to the man who came to betray Him, and endured, such an action as that was, and then proceeded to a thing of far greater daring, the Cross itself, to the death of shame, and there again He manifested His lovingkindness.

[72:91] And here He calleth it "glory," showing us that there is nothing so shameful and reproachful which makes not brighter him who goeth to it, if it be done according to the will of God.

[72:92] At least after the going forth of Judas to the betraying, He saith,  Ver.

[72:93] "Now is the Son of Man glorified".

[72:94] In this way rousing the dejected thoughts of the disciples, and persuading them not only not to despond, but even to rejoice.

[72:95] On this account He rebuked Peter at the first, because for one who has been in death to overcome death, is great glory.

[72:96] And this is what He said of Himself, "When I am lifted up, then ye shall know that I Am" ( c.

[72:97] viii.

[72:98] ); and again, "Destroy this Temple" ( c.

[72:99] ii.

[72:100] ); and again, "No sign shall be given unto you but the sign of Jonas".

[72:101] ( Matt.

[72:102] xii.

[72:103] ) For how can it be otherwise than great glory, the being able even after death to do greater things than before death? for in order that the Resurrection might be believed, the disciples did work greater things.

[72:104] But unless He had lived, and had been God, how could these men have wrought such things in His Name?  Ver.

[72:105] "And God shall glorify Him".

[72:106] What is, "And God shall glorify Him in Himself"? It is "by means of Himself, not by means of another".

[72:107] "And shall straightway glorify Him".

[72:108] That is, "simultaneously with the Cross".

[72:109] "For it will not be after much time," He saith, "nor will He wait for the distant season of the Resurrection, nor will He then show Him glorious, but straightway on the Cross itself His glories shall appear".

[72:110] And so the sun was darkened, the rocks rent; the veil of the temple was parted asunder, many bodies of saints that slept arose, the tomb had its seals, the guards sat by, and while a stone lay over the Body the Body rose; forty days passed by, and the Gift of the Spirit came, and they all straightway preached Him.

[72:111] This is, "shall glorify Him in Himself, and shall straightway glorify Him"; not by Angels or Archangels, not by any other power, but by Himself.

[72:112] But how did He also glorify Him by Himself? By doing all for the glory of the Son.

[72:113] Yet the Son did all.

[72:114] Seest thou that He referreth to the Father the things done by Himself?  Ver.

[72:115] "Little children, yet a little while I am with you—and as I said unto the Jews, Whither I go ye cannot come, so now I say to you".

[72:116] He now begins words of sorrow after the supper.

[72:117] For when Judas went forth it was no longer evening, but night.

[72:118] But since they were about to come shortly, it was necessary to set all things before the disciples, that they might have them in remembrance; or rather, the Spirit recalled all to their minds.

[72:119] For it is likely that they would forget many things, as hearing for the first time, and being about to undergo such temptations.

[72:120] Men who were weighed down to sleep, (as another Evangelist saith,— Luke xxii.

[72:121] ,) who were possessed by despondency, as Christ saith Himself, "Because I have said these things unto you, sorrow hath filled your hearts" ( c.

[72:122] xvi.

[72:123] ), how could they retain all these things exactly? Why then were they spoken? It became no little gain to them with respect to their opinion of Christ, that in after times when reminded they certainly knew that they had long ago heard these things from Christ.

[72:124] But wherefore doth He first cast down their souls, saying, "Yet a little while I am with you"? "To the Jews indeed it was said with reason, but wherefore dost Thou place us in just the same class with those obstinate ones?" He by no means did so.

[72:125] "Why then said He, 'As I said to the Jews'?" He reminded them that He did not now, because troubles were upon them, warn them of these things, but that He had foreknown them from the first, and that they were witnesses who had heard that He had said these things to the Jews.

[72:126] Wherefore He added also the word, "little children," that when they heard, "As I said to the Jews," they might not deem that the expression was used in like sense towards themselves.

[72:127] It was not then to depress but to comfort them that He thus spake, that their dangers might not, by coming upon them suddenly, trouble them to excess.

[72:128] "Whither I go, ye cannot come".

[72:129] He showeth that His death is a removal, and a change for the better to a place which admits not corruptible bodies.

[72:130] This He saith, both to excite their love towards Him, and to make it more fervent.
